It's a good game, but not a great one.
(I've never written a review here, but there is so much hype around this game in late 2019, because of the TV-series, that one can be easily fooled.)
I've spent 67 hours in the game and I still haven't went to Skellige, which to my current understanding is one of the 3 main locations. So it's not a short game.
The scenes are beautiful and the changing circumstances (weather + day/night) are adding different vibes to the same area every time you would return.
Though the character model are rigid which show the age of the game, it's only disturbing in cutscenes with less clothes.
The music being dependent of the location plus the action you are doing can be repetitive if you focus on some tasks, but the single tracks are nice and helping the immersion.
Fast travel points are well placed and dense enough. This leads us to the first annoying thing in the game:
-the horse
Riding your horse meant to help you cover longer distances faster. Taking into account the distance between fast travel posts and how disturbingly buggy it is to call the horse, this becomes a big trouble. The main beauty of the game would be to roam the wild. Instead you spend a minute to get on your horse whistling the whole time, because sometimes it appears under a bridge, in the bridge, stuck in the woods or not at all. You start running to not waste more time and to give another chance to Roach to spawn to a better spot. Then either your reach a fast travel point and miss out half of the game or you mount your horse, become three times more powerful as on foot and slay any monster. Then of course you have to get off the horse to loot some monster blood and you can only wish that you are on a nice open field where Roach can not face an unmovable tree and dash it endlessly.
Another engine bug which can ruin you experience are:
-hints
More like the lack of them. There are basic elements in the game and some I missed out completely because I got a short message about it when I was past level 15. Alchemy was on topic and not only I didn't focus on this, but as a side effect I have also no skills purchased for it. The reason for this is that I tried to play this section of the game without it's help so I compared it to Oblivion, and this one is just far more because so I was overthinking. That game is making a lot more things right for example:
-stealing/looting
This is just a small annoyance to some, but I was used to in Oblivion that you can only freely steal from anyone if you worked hard and became a master thief. This feature is missing here, which means you walk into the house of the poorest family, your best friend or greatest foe and start looting dried fruits from all the cupboards. No one bats an eye, no chill, no fun and feels pretty awkward and morally questionable at the beginning.
But all the previous issues are small disturbances and could be forgiven, not the:
-leveling
I hope there is a well defined sequence you can play this game in a challenging, enjoyable way. But I must beg to differ. The early part was incredibly frustrating and then suddenly easy on that degree that you start questioning why would you start any mission. Why is that? Every task has a suggested level assigned to it. As well every combat item has a minimum level that you can use it. So if you are getting bored following the main quest and want to do some good old hack and slash you head to the woods. Then you realize how under powered you are and try to buff up a little bit. This is the point when it becomes clear making a two minute conversation with someone in a quest where you make 2 "decisions", which are changing a single line in the text from you partner gives you the same amount of XP as killing +4 level beasts for a couple of hours. Reaching level 7 from level 6 took hours, I couldn't wait to be able to use my new sword I saved money for. Then I popped into the city to speed up the process and left level 15, the sword being a garbage sold for 5 golds... The monsters I was struggling with earlier couldn't even slow me down and I have a list of side quest above my level giving 1-2 xp and offering no challenge at all. I even missed out a big chunk of the story as I was sent to north which I followed literally instead of the detour to the east which was foreseen by the writers, but the blockade which you I should have dealt with was only effective there not the other way leading to the destination city.
Now I'm in a world where I can kill dragons with my pinky in one forest and could be teared apart from level 40 wolves in another, having 3 different main storylines which contradict each other(working for someone in one, while I'm planning to kill the person in another). I already have failed mission because I finished another earlier and the player I should have interact with is not available anymore.
As a bonus:
-gwent
is the minigame which kind of confirms, that this is happening not by mistake, but by design. The first rounds you just have no chance. Then there is still tiny little period when you have to make an effort to be successful. The fun part, which is challenging and therefore rewarding. It's not impossibly hard and not blatantly easy. Then you win a few games and it's over. You have such a strong deck, you don't even have to try, you just win and start the grinding, to fast travel to locations search more unique cards, win them in two minutes and restart the cycle.

This game is worth every penny. So much content, even withouth the DLCs, which, btw, are awesome! Specially Blood and Wine. Locations, NPSc, sidequests, monsters, treasure hunts, dialogues, and gwent! Oh yes, gwent. This mini game makes the whole game's price worth it.
With 150+ hours in, I still feel I can squeeze more content out of this game, however I'm 100% satisfied with the amount I was able to play. The storyline keeps you so interested all throughout the main quest. I assure you won't skip any dialogue or scene. With a bunch of action, a sprinkle of humor, and more than a few hot scenes to remember, this game is well deserving of it's praise. How about a round of gwent?

You don't need to have played the first two games to enjoy this installment.
I personally watched the series first, read the books then played this games since it's a "sequel" to the former mediums.
I recommend taking time to play this game properly, because one can rush it in 40 hours while you can play it for at least a 150 hours and still get pleasant surprises.
This is the only game where the side quests are as good as the main story.
The DLCs are absolutely phenomenal and are better than other standalone RPG or AAA games in their entirety.
Having read the books, seeing the characters and the truly rich and detailed world come to life altogether was very pleasant. The Witcher's word is grim but authentic and beautiful at the same time and countless times I have found myself admiring the amount of efforts the devs put into this by meticulously studying Andrezj Sapkowsky's books.
I've played many RPGs but this is by far the best one I've ever played.
Great story
Great combat
Insanely beautiful world and lore
(I recommend reading the books as well, there's 8 of them (the last one actually being a separate prequel) but most are only 300 pages long)
PS: playing the game on Blood and Broken Bones difficulty is definitely worth it

I fell in love with this game, too late, but better late than never.

Wow. An absolute masterpiece. The story is rich and has great character development, really giving you an emotional attachment to characters that I haven't seen from a game of this nature before. The combat is far better than I had even expected, forcing you to use all of the tools at your disposal from your swords to your abilities and potions. The combat has a ton of depth, and a really high skill ceiling if you manage to practice at it- giving you a huge degree of satisfaction when defeating powerful enemies and bosses. The sheer number of unique monsters and enemies types (including bosses) is insane, and shockingly never gets tedious or repetitive. The loot and crafting is the best I've seen from an RPG, as it is deep but not tedious to find the materials you need.
Definitely the closest game I've played to a 10/10- if you're on the fence, definitely pick it up. Throw in some mods like I did for a few quality of life changes, and this becomes a 10.

If I had to pick one quality that stands out the most, I'd say it's the side quests. Just about every side quest has cutscenes with excellent dialogue and usually have multiple choices to make. It makes even the most insignificant sidequest feel important.
As a bonus, both major DLC's are good enough to be standalone one-shot's.
What can i say? The Path never gets old.
Mind Sucking Game!! So Much fun. It has kept me away from my books and I am a 4 book a week type of girl.

As others have said over the years, this game is essentially unmatched for it's attention to detail, storyline, and overall "fun factor". I've put nearly 200 hours into the game, completed all side locations,
and have had two separate playthroughs. And yet, I'VE NEVER FINISHED THE MAIN STORY'S FINAL MISSION, NOR HAVE I PLAYED EITHER OF THE DLC'S. As of 2/27/2020, I am currently reinstalling the game to finally complete that FINAL mission, and play both DLCs.
I am fully prepared to lose my life, job, and sense of self-hygiene to this game again, and I know that I will enjoy every minute of it. Perhaps I won't start the DLCs tonight; perhaps I will create a third playthrough just to experience that novel feeling of fun and discovery. It really is that fun to me.

One of the better games i've ever played (behind Fallout 1 & 2).
Very few RPG's these days live up to the name, they just pretend to, Witcher 3 on the other hand...
PROS
Your choices actually matter - A lot of games with 'choice based' story mechanics only give you the mere illusion of what you say on that dialogue wheel actually matters towards the end goal, like Skyrim or Fallout 4; Not Witcher 3, I was shocked when I got the bad ending my first time through.
Even though you don't necessarily make your character in this game, you make his decisions, and even though you don't form his face in a character creator menu, Geralt feels a lot more like YOURS than any Skyrim character of yours ever will.
The Story has grit - There's rarely good or bad in this game, like I mentioned before your actions have consequences...
You kill a dog to save a boy, the wolf pack for you, you kill a boy to save a dog the whole village is after you.
The gameplay is genuinely fun -
The whole role-playing bit, this game pretty much hits right on the money, no doubt; What about the gameplay part? Well the action is no place to complain either i think.
Sure i've had those "I dodged over there, not over there!" moments or the "I didn't mean to take that potion!" moments, But! It's well rounded, obviously taking influence from the Dark Souls series of games like every other action Action RPG these days but can you really argue? It works and it's fun.
The game doesn't force you to play any specific way. You don't have to use potions, concoctions, or bombs, but if you do, you'll find it completely rewarding when you've planned an epic battle beforehand and find yourself completely ripping through enemies thanks to it.
If you plan right you can turn a challenging battles into a breeze, and it's only because you've prepared yourself.
None of this will be as satisfying though if you don't play on blood and broken bones difficulty... ahem... let me repeat myself... PLAY ON BLOOD AND BROKEN BONES... or death march if you like being pegged...
CONS
Horse jank - Your horse, Roach, can be a lil ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô?at times. Sometimes he has a hard time doing a 360. Resting your horse to regain stamina is a bit gay... but by NO means whatsoever does this take away from how badass this game is deep in. By the end you'll end up naming your next Minecraft horse Roach anyways so what does it matter...
Geralt jank - You move like a robot. What can i say this whole game feels like it's on ice; It's irritating at times but i've never felt like punching a whole through my monitor. ledges are ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•es, fight near water you probably dodge and find your self in the middle of the ocean, and getting on boats is like putting on pants two legs at a time...
IN CONCLUSION
THIS GAME IS GREAT...
The cons are so minor they're practically non-problems and the pros far outweigh any issue you can throw at it.
You'll fall in love with Geralt and his friends, regardless if you had played the last two games or not, I know I didn't. So finally, I recommend that you steal you parents credit card as soon as possible, and hop into this beautiful, beautiful experience as quickly as you can...

‚òëIncredible Graphics which still hold up massively for a game released in 2015
‚òëStory is tough gripping with lots of deeply interesting characters & lore
‚òëCombat is extremely satisfying, with countless different builds you can go so you won't get bored, ever.
‚òëVery addictive always feel like coming back and trying a new build/dialogue options
‚òëMusic is near Skyrim levels of breathtaking with a heavy influence of it, so if you liked Skyrims ambient music & fast battle music you'll love this too
‚òëSide quests are nearly always fun to do with lots of interesting concepts, returning characters from previous games and crazy enemies
‚òëCan import your save from The Witcher 2: Assassin Of Kings which effects some in-game story decisions
‚òëMost of the characters in this game are very likeable/hateble in a very, very good way
‚òëTsundere goth girl that is in love with you but doms you around
‚òíEXTREMELY BUGGY. One of actually no, this is the most buggy game I've played in recent years. A list of some of the few hundred bugs I encountered were: Crashing, loading screens not ending, enemies being stuck in a T pose and easy to kill, falling through the map, not being able to use signs unless you reload, potions not going off and the worst one I came across by far is Level Scailing. TURN THIS OFF! As even RATS can one shot you if you reach a certain level which is absolutely ridiculous and certain fights like the Djinn one becomes impossible with it on if you are a higher level then the quest
‚òíNoticed in dialogue, if you choose an option rarely Geralt doesn't exactly say what you picked just either along the lines of it barely or not relating to it at all. Very rare this happens but noticed it a couple times playing it through twice
‚òíCrafting is VERY expensive late game, so expensive you have to keep finding ways to farm money if you don't have contracts left and want to keep crafting gear/weapons by killing high level enemies and selling their weapons which doesn't always work as smiths have a set amount of money which can run out if you sell them too much
Overall this is a phenomenal game I would arguably say is better then Zelda: BOTW, but bugs hold it back by a lot. In BOTW there is a lot of great ones like launching across the map riding your shield or beating the game from the get go but in this game, the bugs are ONLY an annoyance always hindering your gameplay.

Credit to CD Projekt Red, This has held up through time. beautiful graphics, smooth gameplay and fighting sequences. The game isnt really open world persay, but you can do almost whatever you want.  The story is rich with characters, the dialogue is pretty good, character models are outstanding, and overall a must have, especially on sale. There is so much to do, even without the DLCs. I really cant say anything else new that hasn't already been praised by millions of other people. Just get the game.
There are some downsides. Since there are huge maps, there is a lot of walking, not Borderlands worth of walking, but its a lot. Luckily you can ride your trusty horse Roach around. The crafting is a little intricate, you'll be picking up loads of leaves and herbs, but not end up using most of em for the good stuff. The inventory is pretty decent though, so its makes up for that. There are a few more, but honestly, they get outweighed by the great story line and gameplay. i'm not one that  cares much for story lines, but this one is worth it.

Excellent game if you can forgive the ending, which is pretty much bunk. There are multiple endings, but they depend on what you chose to do at a handful of points in the game. None of the key moments seemed particularly weighty at the time, and the options you are given all seem pretty random, meaning that the various options don't conform to one or another moral/ethical worldview. You make a more or less random choice and you don't find out the consequences until the the game's final cutscene. But this is really a small criticism, or easy to forgive and forget. The game is very deep, has tons of customization of your boy Geralt in both gear and skills. The only other minor quibble is that sometimes combat, especially unarmed combat, is more exhausting for the player (you) than it seems to be for Geralt. Spamming the block and strike buttons for long fights made me worried about carpal tunnel syndrome. Maybe there are better approaches, but I never found them. I regard the more than 150 hours spent on the game as time well spent in any case.

Although the story & characters of The Witcher universe are relatively intriguing, the overall design of the world made it hard to completely enjoy the actual open-world/role-playing aspect of the game. Riding through the world to each destination felt more like a chore, rather than something I was actually looking forward to, thus making it very difficult to find some motivation to progress the story/quests.
The world has some gorgeous vistas from a distance, but when you're actually travelling through these areas in-person, they begin to feel a little bit lifeless.

I bought this game thinking, "great, finally a game all about witches". However, it turns out it is in fact not entirely about witches, despite there being several witches throughout the game. Before you finish letting out that long sigh of disappointment, let me assure you, it is very much so a game about witches.
The game centers around Geralt of Rivia, a 'witcher' who struggles with his identity after being forced to conform to his adoptive family's witcher teachings from a young age, despite self-identifying as a witch. After years of psychological torture and identity crisis, he has come to terms with who he is. Geralt now seeks to break the cycle of identity norms that had both physically and mentally altered his life forever, by finding his old apprentice Ciri and letting her know it's okay to pursue her destiny as a witch. Although there's only several witches throughout the game on your journey to find Ciri, there's plenty of great filler content along the way, including all of the creatures you'd expect in a great witch game like ghouls, imps, werewolves, and ghosts. Now I know what you're thinking, no witch game would ever be complete without magic and potions, and you're right. Thankfully, this game has you covered despite their non-traditional approach. Although Geralt still frequently uses magic, it is not his primary catalyst for destruction as with a typical witch. Nor does he require a cauldron to brew potions or a spell book to cast his spells, but we have the witcher teachings to blame for this. Sadly, the one thing that's definitely missing from this game is the ability to fly, but I'm afraid the witcher teachings have ruined this possibility as well; although to be honest, I'm personally convinced this is solely the result of laziness on the developer's part, but I digress.
Despite needing some work in the witch department, it's probably the closest thing us fans have to a witch game for now. Overall, I'd give it a 10/10 for its endless hours of content, remarkable RPG decisions/consequences, solid combat system, and its resemblance of a witch game. If you are one of those people who aren't expecting this game to be entirely about witches, I'm sure you'll have fewer issues with the game and I would 100% recommend it.

Literally the worst in the series. A direct downgrade from the first two games in every single way save for quantity. And when it comes to The Witcher the last thing I demand is abundance.
The combat is watered down, Alchemy is essentially removed, leveling system gutted and lacking any real progression, Crafting is neat but lacks viability after the first few hours, Choices and consequences are essentially nonexistant (including carry over from your previous games save), Bland boring story with few memorable characters, Level gated zones with bizarre mmo-esque mechanics, Level gated zones with bizarre mmo-esque mechanics, Many quests feel as involved as a radiant quest from Bethesda, This list could go on.
Positives wise Gwent is a lot of fun, The game is very pretty and holds up well, Great music if a bit repetitive after 100 hours.
The DLC is okay and uplifts the base game a bit but certainly nowhere near the overrated hype this game received and continues to get, if you havent played the first two please give them a shot and be open minded.

As a player of both the Witcher 1 and 2, The Witcher 3 is an amazing game to finish off a trilogy. The game immerses you as a Witcher, a mutant mercenary who specializes in killing monsters, tracking lost people, and lifting curses. The game takes you through an amazing story where you make grey moral choices and are up against a formidable seemingly-unstoppable foe. You meet characters with great writing which have their own motives and flaws, everyone seems like a real person. The music in the game can make you feel anything from grief when a character dies to heroic as you slay a wyvern. This game is filled with so much detail that it feels like a love letter from the developers to the fans, this game is a must buy for anyone who is a fan of story centered games with tons of action.

Is The Witcher 3 a bad game? Absolutely not. Is the Witcher 3 a great game? Well, that's going to depend a lot on you. As for myself, despite multiple attempts to get into it, it just fell flat over and over again.
Visually, the game is gorgeous. If you've got a high-end PC, crank up those graphics and enjoy all the work that went into making the world. You're in for a treat.
The story and the mechanics, I think, are going to depend a lot more on you as an individual.
The story begins with you attempting to find Ciri and Yen. Yen is found fairly quickly, while finding Ciri is a much larger quest. As for myself, I've just never been able to muster much enthusiasm for Ciri as a character or how Geralt interacts with her. This takes a lot of the wind out of the sails of the main storyline very quickly. The side quests range from brilliant to incredibly boring and mundane, and it can be hard to tell which are going to be which.
Combat is very showy, but still feels a bit stilted, as it did in the first two games. Some people don't mind this or even enjoy it, but I found it causing a lot of problems in terms of my being able to get into the flow of a fight. There is a ton of stuff for your to craft, if that's something you enjoy, but I found that it generally didn't bring much satisfaction for me and often felt fairly fiddly for minor gains.
Gwent is another large feature of the game, and if you enjoy the card game, there is a lot of possibly enjoyment to be had from playing and building the deck, but it was another spot for myself where I just found myself not really enjoying the process much and wondering why I was doing this.
At the end of the day, I'd say this is a AA studio that managed to produce a AAA game. But my problem is that I find AAA games to feel largely kind of bland and lifeless and the fact the it came from a AA studio who couldn't quiet put the resources into polishing and detailing the mechanics like AAA studios do, end up doing it a disservice. If your primary play and enjoy AAA game studio products, this is absolutely worth a buy. It's a chance to see how smaller developers make up for their lack of money to blow on the strength of stories and making strong mechanical systems that create interesting game play loops.
If you're primarily an Indie Game or AA studio supporters, your mileage may vary. It can often times feel like a game design to be much smaller, instead spread out and stretched thin over too much game time. If can often times feel like a story that should have been better that was watered down a bit for mass appeal. But the core systems are still strong, perhaps just not as strong as they could have been.
I'm giving this game a thumbs down for me, but that's just out of recognition that it isn't really a game designed for people like me. Not because it's a poor game.

The life as a gamer would be divided - Before you've played 'The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt', and after...
How many times you've received recommendation of a game and red critics that praise it, and then played it just to find it's even better than the critics says? This is the rare and wonderful scenario with the Witcher 3.
Although coming with the highest expectations, the quality of the game caught me of guard, surprised of how it perfected the modern gaming experience. 'Why' you ask? what is so good about it?
It's not tons of gamers follow as sheep, praising it because its popular to, the truth is that the Witcher excel every category -
Incredible graphics and design, that would make it a thrill to explore, full of HUGE amount of content, events and adventures to make your life feel boring without, super solid RPG elements crafted wisely, breathtaking soundtrack, intriguing gameplay and animations, and if that's not enough, and most important in the gaming world now days -
Magnificent story telling - not because its unique, but because every character lives and breathes through dialogue and great voice acting, using a well detailed script which give every one of them the complex and sense of realism, that would make you care for so many of them.
This game is so packed with areas and quests, endless options and decision to make, and what you choose is going to take effect, so you should always keep that in mind.
If I'd try to find points to improve (I needed to search so much for it) - The RPG core of the game, that is a bit overflowed and maybe overdone containing amount of items and elements to deal with, feels so many times scattered and overwhelming not in a good way, and you won't feel like going over so many of them, and ignore a lot of items.
But if it's the only thing that wasn't perfect, who am I to complain?
To sum up - I don't have lot of patient for endless RPG's, but 192 HOURS ON RECORD just flew by! Anything left to say?
Thank you, CD Project Red, for changing the life of countless gamers!

Well put together game but not without its flaws and contrary to popular belief definitely NOT a masterpiece.
Using the boat has got to be one of the most tedious and boring parts of the experience, that's one part of the game I tried to avoid as best I could. For a person like myself, who likes making sure all of the maps in games I play are filled out, I stopped checking each question mark after I realised that the majority of them, especially in Skellige (specifically the ones on water) are absolutely useless. There is little to no incentive to collect loot for any reasons other than selling it as your Witcher gear will always be better than anything you come across. This ruins any satisfaction I would have with exploring this otherwise very beautiful and immersive world. There just doesn't seem to be a priority in throwing a bone at the player for curiosity and adventure, which is present in many other games of this and previous generations...
There are still many things I can't remember off the top of my head, however despite all its flaws I still stuck through with the game as the highs in quests and storytelling certainly do reach a high peak in certain parts. I'll be lying if I said I didn't immensely enjoy the stories told in the Witcher 3. It's definitely the strongest part of the game - the writing and interesting characters.
If you love western RPGs or action RPGs then you've already played this game. If you don't know what a WRPG/ARPG is, then this is an easy choice to pick up to try out as a first. I find this game quite simple once you learn a few intricate parts such as potion management and properly casting signs.

Life is too short to spend it playing games like The Witcher 3. The game seems to exist for the purpose of occupying your time. The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt, other than Earthbound, is the game I've put most hours into. 522 at the time of this review. It's a really impressive game for what it is, a sequel to 2 rather ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• games (imo). The open world is one of the best in gaming, only beaten out by Zelda Breath Of The Wild. But this sadly is not a great achievement like it might sound like. Most open worlds in games are pretty bland and boring with billions of things to that are all the same at the end of the day. Though this world feels more alive and interesting than those other ones, it's still cursed with rather boring tasks like killing bandits in their camp, or in an abandoned village, or monsters in a cave and monsters in their nests. All which reward pretty useless stuff.
The combat also lacks, once you get a hang of it. Dodge, attack and repeat endlessly it gets easy as ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•. Even on death march. The hardest difficulty. Though the swift moves and dance like sword play is pretty fun at times like when meeting humanoid enemies.
Where The Witcher really shines, and I mean REALLY shines, is at the side quests. They are by far the best I've ever played through. Almost all have really unique and fun stories attached to them and most hide that they're fetch quests rather well. Highlights for me are Where the Cat and Wolf Play (Free dlc quest) and Carnal Sins.
Speaking of DLC, both expansions are very good, Hearts of Stone being the best of the two, but Blood and Wine providing most of the content will bring you most of the playtime when comparing the two. There is also free DLC like quests and other addons that are circlejerked to oblivion and beyond. Sure they are cool, Cat and Wolf is a highlight. But not more special than free content other devs add to their games. So why it's a "plus" when people recommend the game to others is something I don't really understand. The free DLC can be skipped and not much would be missed (other than cat and wolf of course)
Graphics are good but sound is odd and feels off at times. Everytime the Wild Hunt is on camera, it sounds like the most dramatic of sound effects were added to a guy getting of a horse. The inns also have this weird crowd noise when it's like two people in there. There are plenty of other sound issues but none that really bother me. Soundtrack is also rather meh.
I might sound negative in this review which is odd as I'm recommending it, but this game is still so ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing good even though it has some flaws. I was never really bored when playing and the immersion levels were through the roof. I really recommend you play this game atleast once, including it's DLC. You can get plenty of hours out of this beast. I would say around 70 your first time around.
Also Gwent is bad, fight me. Yes it's a minigame but it has ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• balance. If you have an okay deck you'll never lose, and I mean NEVER.

I played for awhile, then I realized, how boring and repetitive the story actually is.
Story goes actually like this...
Find Ciri. Find Ciri. Find Ciri... ok, why do I have to find Ciri again? I already forgot...
Who knows about Ciri? No idea. Ok, let's ask a witch... she knows nothing. Ok, let's ask someone else. He knows nothing. Once you find a guy who knows something about Ciri, he won't tell you. He wants favour A and B and C and then only he tells you. So you go around and around and around and do all kind of favours for all kind of people... not, that these have to do anything with the actual main story. Nada.
Ok, so once you do all kind of favours for Guy A he tells you what you know about Ciri. And where is she now? He has no clue. Why the heck did I had to do all this, I'm actually no further. So, you start over again. The whole thing starts from beginning. Go to another place and ask all kind of people to see who knows something about Ciri. Finally, another Guy B knows something but he won't tell you either, because he too wants favours from you .... and so the whole  thing keeps repeating and keeps repeating and keeps repeating.
Wait... why did we do all this in the first place? By the time you're done with all the favours, it's no wonder, you've forgotten why that even mattered... after all, you're only doing things for others and nothing is for you.
You realize, your character is actually boring. The actual storyline could also not matter to you at all (not like in Skyrim, where YOU are DRAGONBORN), after all, you have no emotions anyway as everyone says, so effectively, you do not truely care about others.
You realize, The Witcher 3 has actually nearly no story at all... if you remove all the noise. Take just a handful of the loading cutscenes in between and the true _main_ story is told. The rest, noise which is unimportant.

+ A solid storyline that ties up most of the main dangling threads from throughout the series.
+ Interesting side quests
+ Fun alchemy and oils system to optimize combat.
-Combat gets boring after a while. Enemies do not have much variation in their attack patterns and some appear so often it gets monotonous.
-Opaque dialogue choices. While some would argue that this is part of the appeal, it's annoying for Geralt to not have any kind of inner monologue to hint at what the "proper" choice may be in his eyes. This is especially true with some important decisions in the main questline towards the end of the game.
-Bugged map. Many locations do not load merchant icons properly, making it a massive pain to locate the proper merchant for buying/selling certain goods.

This is it. This is the bar. It's been five years and I don't think anyone else has come close to topping it.
The only RPGs that come near this for me are Zelda: Breath of the Wild, Persona 5, Fallout 1 & 2, and JRPGs like Chrono Trigger and old Final Fantasy. So, in other words, RPGs that are almost nothing like The Witcher 3.
Note that I originally played this on PS4 before I got a good PC and used a save file to start my PC game with the main questline complete, so I've actually played for around 200 hours, something I've never done with any other game.
I'm not saying it's perfect, it's not. But it tries so much more than any other game and gets basically everything right. Except for that ****** fall damage. Speaking of small annoyances that are easily fixed with mods, there also lots of solid mods! My personal favorite is Immersive Cam by KCS.

The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt is a 2015 action role-playing game developed and published by CD Projekt and based on The Witcher series of fantasy novels by Andrzej Sapkowski. It is the sequel to the 2011 game The Witcher 2: Assassins of Kings, played in an open world with a third-person perspective.

The Witcher 3 is one of the best open word RPG's to come in recent memory.
It consists of a vast, beautiful open world, complete with interesting characters, secrets awaiting discovery and a day/night cycle that doesn‚Äôt break immersion.
The combat feels fluid and Geralt‚Äôs blows have weight to them. Enemy variety is limited, but sufficient to keep you on your toes throughout the game, especially on the higher difficulties.
The story, perhaps the most important aspect of any RPG, keeps you moving forward and eager to learn more.
All in all, a AAA RPG that has stood the test of time very well so far and will continue to do so for years to come.

What can I say? I've played the first 2 games and each one gets better and this is no different. In fact, this is one where it's truly open for you to wander, explore and find hundreds of side missions. In fact, you would be doing yourself a disservice NOT to explore everywhere. Useful items are abound. And the combat system is not a button mashfest. The story itself is intriguing and detailed. More so than the first two games. This is probably the best game yet I've ever played as far as RPGs go. The environments are lush, vibrant and alive. The story deep, detailed and immense as is the world at your fingers. Getting lost in it is not difficult and you never want to come out of it nor have it end.
Plot is involved and engaging. I'm quite enjoying it.

Fun game.

I only really played this game in early 2020 I have owned it since I believe 2016 or sooner to when it came out.  When it came out on switch I bought it and gave it another shot but on the go. I gave it more of my time and really payed attention to the games story and great details and it has been a great journey to see. I have not used many of the games great deep systems such as oils or potions to make my life easier I really enjoyed the story and some challenge but even without this the game still feels deep and if you want to use those you can but I didn't meaning its an option not needed to have fun. Granted the game has some flaws like there are so many characters that you can't care for them all some you need to help and while doing that you can't wait for the mission to be over. Loot seems to be you need to find it early or don't craft anything as exploring as a few levels higher causes your gear to be better than anything you can find, BUT it makes really good stuff to sell such as swords that are hundreds of crowns. If you complete all the side missions as they come and often explore all the question marks on the map you obtain many weapons and armor if you sell that You won't need to worry of money like me having always more than 15 thousand without really trying and just spending when I want on crafting my gear. I will say nothing about the story other than I liked it you need to believe you are Geralt and shouldn't do anything he wouldn't like being with a woman even though he loves someone else and  this can cause negative things later in game. By playing slow it really is slow I have played for hours exploring and getting like 50 EXP but less than a full main mission gives 500 EXP normally, contracts and side missions never give the same amount of EXP like a main mission but it can give at one time a few hundred crowns or an item worth selling and crowns or a good item (good item isn't too often) the side mission never really feel the same other than maybe doing looking around with your senses but thats what makes a witcher. Combat is very rewarding like when using a good spell in the mix or not getting hit or the finishers that cut limbs off of enemies is really cool to watch. Crafting is defintly a friend being if you don't craft then you won't be at full potential and the things to craft isn't hard to come by if you kill and loot all your monsters then that is fine or if its something that can be bought at a merchant with your thousands of crowns. I still have more to do like the DLCs but if anything else comes to mind that I wish to add I will edit to give a better review to anyone that is thinking of this game. If your on the fence then don't buy it now wait for a sale or the time this is a game that requires many hours and full attention you need to give it a shot as it throws many things at you right out the gate. If you will give it the time and are on the fence it is a good game I have no clue about your game standards but I enjoy open world games and it is a good one. If you wish to try it steams refund policy is great just set a timer for about and hour and a half so you can stop the game and make a decision. It should give you the main set up within the first 90 min so you can see if it is something you enjoy. I would not recommend if this is a game that will be boughten than never played like me the first time, to enjoy you need to listen and make the right choices to have a connection to the characters and story and the world.  It says I have played the game on steam for about 19 hours that not including switch in a recent update it allows me to play on my switch on the go then at home continuing the same save on PC but on my switch I have roughly 70 hours. I hope you have reached the end of this and that I have been able to help you in buying this game or seeing if it was right for you.

I wished for a fast, long, story rich, cinematic, realistic game.
I set my expectations way too high.
The story is kinda interesting, but not for me really.
If you like rich story games but are slightly impatient, you will hate this game.
There are a lot of other basic things that I hate about the game.
The unnecessary amount of overlay destroys the athmosphere.
From a game which puts a lot of work into athmosphere and design,
you would expect that NPCs are decently reacting realistically,
But sometimes they just do not care about the fact
that some of their companies just died and completely ignore it.
You go into a bar and because you saved the son of the tavern keeper, she says that you can buy stuff for free,
but then it doesn't apply practically. You still have to buy stuff.
Yeah, it would be too easy, but also realistic.
Sometimes, Mods walk into each other in conversations with the player,
NPC reaction animations do not change over fluently, makes them look like crazy witches.
Unrealistic destroyed villages: Usually, you would not see armies leaving behind some villagers, rather than enslaving, killing or ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• them. The same goes for buildings or the only single coat of arms in the middle of the village.
More realistic would have been half dead or completely dead villagers. Anything but this.
The combat system is not special, just the usual.
I have never experienced such boredom in a video game.

After playing this game on PC for a solid 10 hours, I fell off it hard. A few years down the road, I was gifted the game on Nintendo Switch. I decided to give it another go, and totally fell in love with the world, the characters, and the game as a whole. I put around 65 hours in on Switch, and have started the DLC on there, but I always felt like I was getting a lesser experience of the game on that console. I dreamed to have cross save functionality, and hoped it would one day come so I could experience the game back in its wonderful fidelity on PC. Fast forward to today, where cross save has finally come!!! I booted the game up on PC, with my Switch save, and am beyond thrilled to continue my journey on PC at home, and keep playing on Switch on the go. Huge props to CDPR and Saber for making this happen. Awesome work on an awesome, gamer friendly, video game and ecosystem.

Wow. Where do I even begin.
This game is one of the most mesmerizing, electrifying, phenomenal RPGs I've ever got to play.
During my run-down on my Game of the Decade (for entertainment purposes), I couldn't help but return to Geralt in this beautiful story-rich game.
You aren't a hero desperately trying to save the world, nor a villain waiting for it to decay. You are Geralt of Rivia, a monster-hunting witcher with a personal journey of finding your surrogate daughter, Cirilla.
You will come across a desolate, realistic world filled with complex, mature story lines and themes awaiting the players who decide to ignore their real-life responsibilities in order to live through Geralt with the potential
What, personally, puts the
in front of every other open-world RPG title is that each and every distraction from the main quest feels meaningful and impactful rather than an empty map-event. In an age where countless developers seem to fill their games with repetitive side-quests and boring events with no consequences, it‚Äôs undoubtedly refreshing to see worthwhile content brimming from potentially the biggest open-world game ever.
Whether you‚Äôre new to the series or a Witcher saga veteran, you‚Äôll continue to learn new things about Geralt and his world as time goes on, allowing your game-play to feel fresh every step of the way.
Kudos to CD Project RED for this masterpiece.

WITCHER 3
First of all, I've heard of this game since 2018 when i first got my laptop. I know this game because it is always on the top sales.2 years later, I bought this game last week and spent 122 hours to finish the game on Blood and March Difficulty, discovered most of the question mark on the map, finished both DLC, upgraded all my weapons and finished with a satisfying ending.
Pros of this game:
- Thick plot and very interesting story line, got attached to the story line right after i finished the Baron quest, awful ending but understand happy ending exists only in fairy tail.
- Good combat system, thought the camera angle is not really fully developed but it is great than you can dodge and roll, cast spell, bombs, crossbows, parry, counterattack. Various of combat styles is the unique part of being a witcher, two swords but the combat style is always different.
- Balance Enemy system, there's an upscaling button in the game which you can witch off or on, enhance the game experience as the previous monsters are not easily defeated when you're on higher level. Besides, you can always challenge some of the higher level enemies using specific skills and spells, not to say it is guaranteed that you will win but proud to slay a witcher contract which is not on your level.
- Travel system, in an open world game traveling is the most unpopular option for most of the players, fast travel is preferred because it actually saves a lot of time. There are tons of marker on the map which you can discover and never have to travel again.
- Crafting System seems good as there is filters, ingredients that are needed for alchemy or crafting can be pinned and will highlighted in a white box whenever you visits the shop.
Dismantle is the key in saving a lot of time for the resources needed in some crafting.
- Graphics, simply awesome and you will most definitely felt like you're in Velen, Novigrad, Toussaint and Skillige. There are epic views such as sunset, mountains, ruins, castle and so on.
Cons of this game:
- UI for inventory, from my opinion, this inventory looks like something from the warcraft time. It is not bad but there's room to improve.
Overall game experience : 9/10
Playback Rate                   : 8/10
Storyline                           : 10/10

I have tried my hand at countless open world games, some of the more modern ones like RD2, god of war 4 and the like. Simply put those are not the type of game for me, i can get a few hours of enjoyment but then i lose interest, the story doesnt hold me, the gameplay gets repetitive, i dont care about the world im playing within.
With that said this game has sat in my steam library for probably 3 years picked up on sale without being played, for the exact above statements.  Sure I heard all the rave reviews but its just not my type of game right? Well i was so very very wrong. I am sure like many of you after watching the TV series my interest was once again peaked. I always wanted to start with witcher 1 and 2 but I could never make it farther than an hour or two in, the TV series gave me enough background info that I felt able to simply skip those games and I am sure glad I did. The story and world crafted in the game is leagues above anything else I have ever played. The sheer amount of things you can do, decisions you can make, side quests that appear simply by just walking down a city ally and being approached by a stranger that leads to a detailed intricate line of quests. It is all perfectly crafted to make a living world with characters and stories you honestly care about. Take my advice if anything about this story peaks your interest, and even if you are like me who could never seem to make it more than a few hours in to an open world game. Give this one a shot, im 77 hours in and still going, yet to beat the game, but I have yet to slow down.

I've played some open world RPGs in my brief years, and i can say that this game is the best i've played.
Maybe not because it has the best combat, or the most freedom of choice, not even the best graphics maybe?
But everything it has, is polished and well executed, and everything is in harmony.
The aspects i could take are:
- Gameplay: Simple mechanic of two buttons + spells, while also having the two swords. It would seem it's narrow, but the variety of enemies make you use the simple mechanics in A LOT of ways to defeat the great variety of enemies. It has really well done bosses and fights.
- Graphics: Polished and very beautifully crafted. It might not have the most realistic graphics for that year even, but it has a lot of detail, good lightning and textures.
- Bugs: In 2020, i can say they have patched them into oblivion.
- Story: It's a damn good story, but it has a downside. The main antagonists are not very well explained and shown. We don't know them enought to really have THAT impact. Everyone else in the story though, they have their share of background.
A very well executed and polished game, which is even today a standard for the genre.
I have only played the Main Story, and i'm eager to play the DLC soon.
Oh, by the way, this game inspired me to make my first Steam Review, so, hurray!

This is THE best RPG i have played, the reasons for me making this claim are not without evidence.
One of the main reasons is the story which is jaw dropping, from white orchard to the swampy areas of Velen to the renowned city of Novigrad to the Great Witchers keep of Kaer Morhen, each area has its own decisions that will impact the way your story goes.
The game also has excellent replayability as the game has so so many choices, these range from impacting your game at the moment or in the far future, what build will you go, who will you side with, it can even be what hairstyle you want.
Second, is that the artstyle is still breathtaking to this day, from the monsters, buildings, people, and much more. All these things mend together to immerse you into the games astonishing setting and atmosphere. One thing i feel could have been improved apon was the hair.
Third, is the witcher contracts. this is because the witcher contracts arent just go here and kill this, they each have there small storys in them witch is just a +1 in the replayability of the game
Fourth is the gameplay in my opinion it is a huge improvement compared to the witcher 2, which had cluncky combat mechanics in my opinion, also in the Witcher 3 each fight seemed to have a soul as the excellent combat mechanics were woven with the incredible music of the witcher 3.
Fifth is the music, this is because no matter where you are, this could be, standing, running, riding, sailing, or fighting the music has a way to throw you into the beautiful but harsh world of the Witcher 3.
Last is the difficulty of the game, if its your first time and you just want the story than theres a difficulty for that, where as if you want a difficult challenge you can go DM (Death March) as i did and turn on upscaling
So this is the end of my review, i could keep going on about diagrams and more but i have laid out the main points in my opinion.

One of the best game ever made. You al;ready heard all about it... but this game is still the industry leader in 3 points in particular:
1-Story telling: The strongest point by far of witcher 3 is easily its story telling. When side quest have better storyline and more engaging that 90% of rpgs main stories out there, you know you are in for a treat. Seriously, some of theses quests will haunt you.. in a good way, for a long long time.
2- World building: Red dead redemption came pretty much equal but only theses two games have such a believable world, you think its real.
3- Real choices and real consequences: You are not playing good or evil... forget this stupid concept. Like real life, you make choices and theses choices have consequences.. The consequences can be good according to you or evil according to your best friend... It is all but perception. You save a guy one day only to find out he was a criminal the second day? You let someone of dubious morale die and you find out the next day he could have cured cancer? Well, you do not know and you will not see it coming in witcher 3 either.  You make choices all the time.. so much it becomes very difficult to know when one will change the ending or does not change much in the end... and this is en excellent feeling. It feel real, it feel true.
In witcher 3, you might be in a puppet show but not once will you see the strings. Enjoy the ride.
P.S.: This game is 5 years old and is still one of the most (if not THE most) beautiful game you can play !!

OK, I've been hesitant as to how to really understand what  keeps me playing this game, because at times it's as open and interesting as Fallout, and other times it seems like it was written by a group of 13-year-olds really into Dungeons and Dragons. Ultimately I can say this, it's a fun game and worth slogging around in. BUT, if you're a veteran gamer, there are more plot holes and logic gaps than are really tolerable.
In general this is a vast improvement on the previous  Witcher games. The controls are good, the menus feel more comfortable, and the dozen plus keyboard shortcuts give this a hearty PC feeling, unlike the previous 2 games with felt like grinding console ports. There are some fantastic towns, ruins, caves, and terrain. In 54 hours of game play there are less than 5 interesting NPC's. That's the heart of the problem, right there.
Witcher 3 is a huge world, with hundreds of people, dozens of animals, even more monsters, a smooth combat system with great brutal kill effects. The story limps along with numerous distractions, the inconsistent idea of the nature and demeanor of a Witcher distracts from the character, and frequent lack of conversation options gets annoying. There are several times already that a major story plot is gaffed into something that makes very little sense, but the story moves on, leaving the mess behind without consequence. Not an error, not a glitch, just a lazy decision to leave something out that could explain what happened, rather than a "Nothing to see here, move along" feeling.
However, if you played games like Icewind Dale, Diablo, Fallout, or Grand Theft Auto V, you can find a big world to explore, things to do, and even find a few really amazing moments that are truly unique. However, if you want a story that's really going to grip you and not let go, this probably won't do the job. It's not F.E.A.R. or Half-Life. Granted, I'm old, but I really want something more from a game. Witcher 3 just seems half-finished, lacks focus, and ultimately falls short on making a really good game about ghosts and monsters and the mystic warrior who hunts them, instead flirting with confusing politics, loose magic rules, and far too many flat and boring quests from bland characters. Too bad.
I got the worst ending and i need therapy but overall great game 10\10

This game is so incredible.  I am not sure why I see folks complaining about the cut scenes.  Yeah there are a lot, but you don't have to select every dialogue if you don't want (it highlights the main ones in yellow).  Besides, I am finding the cut scenes to be absolutely amazing and hardly ever want to skip them!  If I do, I just read the sub-titles and then it allows me to hit space to skip.  Honestly though, I am not one to usually want to read everything but this game is making me want to since the story is so good.  I am finding myself reading all the books, reading about all the characters, and the beastiary.  The whole story and game is immersive and the way you have to use your Witcher senses and learn about your enemies to know to use against them is outstanding.  The fighting is very good, the magic is fun to use, and the monsters are awesome.
Simply an outstanding game. I hope they come out with another one after I finish this one.  If you are on the fence, just go ahead and buy it, I guarantee you won't be disappointed.  This game really makes me feel like I am the Witcher and that I am making various choices along the way that affect the game.
Hands down, one of the best games I've played in a very long time.

Slow to start, difficult controls for a newcomer to the series that hasn't played the previous ones. But overall a delight to play, the story is thus far concise and seemingly linear. After a challenging but merciful learning curve of the games main mechanics the controls become natural. Would definitely recommend to anyone looking for a game to dive into for hours with lots of content and well developed story, setting, and mechanics.

This game's got great visuals, music, story, characters, it's all very interesting, save for the gameplay part. Contrary to the decisions you might make in the story, nothing you do in the game matters.
You can win fights by just slashing away at random, with the occasional defensive move or spell. It doesn't matter if you specialize towards melee, magic or potions, you can still win fights without any actual investment or effort, even on max difficulty. The only thing you need to worry about is not fighting enemies that are at a level much higher than your own, because a level 20 bandit is capable of slaying a
level 10 witcher, trained for battle and with decades of experience, with a single attack.
Your gear doesn't matter, because the gear you pick up off the ground is enough to carry you through the game, so no need for crafting. A ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• mace you pick off some dead bandit is somehow better than supposedly legendary swords you craft or obtain from quests, just because it's a higher level.
If you enjoyed the preparation aspect of previous witcher games, which is supposedly a big part of being a witcher, that aspect is gone. You can apply oils, drink potions and re-equip gear mid-fight, no preparation required.
The game has all these mechanics that could be interesting and engaging, but it isn't built with them in mind. It's built for you to blaze through it however you want to, just so you can experience the story and characters, which, to be fair, are the best part of the game. It's also got a ton of content, certain to keep you busy for a hundred of hours, if not more.
In conclusion, if you want a massive adventure with an interesting story and characters, great music and beautiful visuals, you will most likely enjoy this game. On the other hand, if you want an engaging video game, look elsewhere.

The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt is a great game with a creative world with a likeable protagonist, that has a healthily mixed relationship between immersive storytelling and innovative combat. For starters, from the first second you start the game, you are greeted with a cutscene detailing and building the world you are about to delve into. The fantasy setting fits the characters perfectly, with you playing as Geralt of Rivia, a witcher. He works well as a protagonist, because he isn't a blank slate for the player to impose themselves onto, but rather a deep and well thought-out character with internal conflicts of his own. The storytelling is immersive, allowing the player to make story-altering decisions and responses as Geralt to suit their own personality. Not only this, but the combat is fleshed out enough to allow the player to have their own playstyle. Want to craft oils and bombs to suit the enemy you are fighting? You can choose to do that, but it isn't necessary. Want to use magic to devastate the enemy? You can do that. The upgrades and glyph system allow players to form their own unique playstyle, and this makes the combat feel very rewarding. All in all, The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt is a game I would highly recommend to anyone who wants an immersive fantasy experience.

The developers really put a lot of love into this game. There are just so many things to do in game, so many areas to explore and hidden things to collect, and even a few side activities like horse racing and gwent (which is really fun if you're into card games).

The Witcher 3 is an excellent narrative open world RPG that excels on almost all levels. I have very few complaints with this game and have played through the story multiple times. Even if you don't enjoy open worlds I would still recommend it for the story. Almost all of the side missions are interesting and exciting, and there's always a reward, a twist or a one-liner at the end of every quest. However, if you do not like story focused games, this one is not for you. There is a lot of dialogue and story you have to pay attention to, so you better not skip dialogues or you are going to get lost.
Pro tip: Do the side quests that you are give through the main story as some of them will disappear after progressing through the story.

The Witcher 3: The Wild Hunt is one of the very few rare games that I sit there staring at my screen not knowing what do I write or what do I say about them, I feel like words are short and expressions are meaningless when you are simply dealing with perfection, beauty, and enjoyment and thus I find myself unable to let out what's inside me towards this masterpiece of a game, it's that good.
The Witcher 3: The Wild Hunt captures the storytelling and characters from the Witcher1 and makes it better, The Witcher 3: The Wild Hunt captures the combat from Witcher2 and makes it better; it takes all that and puts it into an open world of incredibleness and quality.

a sad feeling that this life journey is over.

There are hundreds of thousands of positive reviews for the Witcher 3 - mine is no different.
I originally played this game on PS4. I remember when I first got it, I played up until the Bloody Baron and then I lost interest. Started out a new game when the DLC was coming out and I was hearing great things. Instantly sucked a few hundred hours of my life. I thought back then this was the greatest game ever made.
I upgraded to a slightly newer PC that could actually run the game and decided to give the game another go after watching the Netflix series. For a game that is almost 5 years old, this is still the best game ever made. It has aged a little and the the combat isn't as seamless as other games that have been released since; however it is still the pinnacle of story-telling. This is high fantasy and the game/story is massive. I think people that don't like the game couldn't get into it and found the story/lore confusing. I hope the Netflix series can get people into this game and book series more; because the Witcher is an amazing story and should be considered a major rival to the LOTR-universe.
If you have not yet played The Witcher 3 you are failing at life.
One of the best games ever played!
Game of the decade, simple as that.

Waow... I have no words.
What an absolute waste of time and money.
Okay okay, so: First off, I've tried playing The Witcher 1... didn't even get past the tutroial, so that set a bar for me right from the start. Now I've heard so many great things about The Witcher 3 through the years, but I kept my distance because of an extremely bad and unsatifying experience.
With that said, I decided to give The Witcher 3 a try... and oh boy do I regret everything about it.
First thing that messes with me is the mouse sensitivity, either you put that thing ALL the way down and make navigation in menus insufferably slow, but your camera doesn't fly round when you're in character mode... or you just have 2000% motion blur all the time, but are able to normally navigate menus.
So... Actually starting a new game! Now, as a brand new player to the series, I went all in on the tutorials, getting things explained and shown, little did I know I would have to sit and just read for  hours before the game itself even started... or well, the games tutorial started. at this point I was already considering whether this was worth it, since this lowered every expectation I already had... I mean how can I be expected to remember all this stuff with no way of getting it explained again unless I have to break the pace of the game, minimize it and google stuff?
So getting to moving around... barely, every time I move what seems no more then 10 meters, there's a new pop-up giving me another "this is important, you do it like this, which will affect the world you play in" generic message. Cool choices matter, I get that by now.
So (extremely) slowly and with a ton of pauses because of explanations, I FINALLY get to the combat section of the tutorial. And what do I get... never before have I had to read that much to understand a combat system. I could go on about the wall of text new players are met with.
After finnishing reading more stuff about this minor obscure detail in combat, I get to the actual thing... It's worse than Skyrims system. Extremely clunky, free-targeting-city unless you choose one specific target... which somehow always ends up in the back ranks so you might as well retarget, and suddenly, that target is in the back ranks... oh my lord. At this point I'm about ready to give up, Heavily discouraged by what feels like The Shakespere Collection in text, that has to be read and understood, and utter stupidity in combat systems. But I press on becuase there has to be some light at the end of this tunnel.
Welcome to the actual game itself. Now please have en eternaty of go-here-do-this quests with absoultly no diversity. And if you wanna defeat this foe you've never seen before... guess what, you have to break the pace of the game, stop combat and read even more about how to even damage a Noonwraith.
So at an all-time low in-game, I decide to try to get some more exp so I can be at least somewhat useful... Oh wait, let's pause the game becuase, during the tutorial we didn't make you read about skill points, brewing potions or weapon durability.
Just great...
After actually giving up on reading and just wanting to mess around, I slam my space button and just skip it, deciding to figure it out at some point when I really need it.
So finally leaving the starting... town? I suddenly encounter an enemy that's no more then TWO WHOLE LEVELS above me... and suddenly all of my attacks are reduced by 90% in damage... Are you actually for real?... Fine whatever... I'll flee and come back later... but oh wait, your health is low and you can only heal by eating food which is horrendously slow... Now please be attacked by 8  Drowners at the same time, which all stun you and kills you... and btw you didn't save so please redo all your missions.
I finally just gave up and closed the game.
So what did I learn.
- Unless you're willing to come out of the game with a PHD in Witcher stuff, don't open it up.
- Whatever you try to do, assume you have to read about it in some random book, stupid pop-up or your journal.
- Combat is insanely clunky, even if you side roll enemies still hit you and you lose 1/3 of your HP from lesser monsters... You never ever have the chance to counter attack because of sheer numbers disadvantage... And why do I have to choose between 2 different swords to even damage propperly (This should be something that comes naturally... not something a player should activly choose)
- Story is very unimmersive and flat. at least the tiny bits I got to "experience" (Seriously, just 2 edge-lrods in some tavern)
- There are so many systems that are so extremely confusing to new players, that they don't even bother learning them
- The leaning curve in this game just requires you to be a working at NASA.
- Unless you can connect a controller, the game is insufferable with mouse and keyboard.
- The game, AT LEAST, uses a nice color palette.
Edit: Having taken a small breather and looking at the review again, I have to say: I've completly lost any interest in gaming as a whole for the rest of the day. I really have to force myself to keep a propper tone and not curse left and right. My hands are almost shaking and I have to keep taking deep breaths and remind myself that "It's just a game"... That's how insufferable and frustrating this game is.
Their is real life, and then their is Witcher life. I live in the former and not the latter

I never played the first two games and picked this up four years after it came out. I knew it had good a reputation, but I wasn't expecting much.
The atmosphere and ambience is stunning like nothing else I've ever seen or heard. I expect that you will amass quite the trove of screenshots.
The storytelling is gripping. There are some questionable events, and all the side quests (interesting as they are) don't really make sense given the sense of urgency of the main plot, but overall... wow. One day I am definitely going to read the books.
I recommend playing on the hardest difficulty: learning to become a competent witcher is not easy (it makes the start of the game very hard), but there is a rhythm to combat that will let you consistently survive, and I found it fun to hold myself to a high bar knowing that death was always a few missteps away. No witcher has ever died in his bed.

This game is amazingly fun.  I feel it is one of the best if not the best RPG game out there.
BUUUUUUUT there are a couple mods I recommend installing just for quality of life improvements.
---If you have a display driver crash (frequently Open GL) just turn off g-sync/ v-sync
1-Fast Travel From Anywhere- This mod feels essential.  However I recommend playing through the game once without it just so you can get the full immersive gameplay.
2-Custom bets in gwent games - not necessary, but I felt that if Garalt has the coin why not let him bet all his money on 1 round of gwent, F-it  why not.
3-Run/Jump in shallow water - I am not sure if this was actually added to the base game or not, but I always have it installed since its just stupid to think that a witcher cannot jump or move faster than a slow walk while in shallow water
Outside of installing those, It is a wonderful game that you can play over and over again and still find new stuff.

This is definitely one of the best games I've played. The pace of this game goes hand in hand with your own play-style.
For a game made in 2015 it still holds up really well graphically and gameplay-wise.
The main issue regarding some open world games is that some parts of it feel dead. This is not the case with Witcher 3 as every community, even the forests and seas have their own form of life and culture.
You have choice in this game as well, and whilst you can go about killing everyone, you would also feel the same satisfaction from not killing and befriending someone that could have been your enemy.
The RPG element is also properly fleshed out to make your character strong but not so strong that it makes the game overly easy. It it worth noting that it does have a learning curve but once it is figured out, you can build the main character to suit your play-style.
The amount of attention to detail in this game feels like they made the game and let it marinate by having playtesters.
Some games you get tired of the UI and the game mechanics, but in Witcher 3, you can interact in so many different ways, it takes really long before it gets repetitive.
Lets talk about the music. This game's soundtrack is definitely one of the best ever. I have even began listening to the music on YouTube when trying to do other work-related tasks.
Different locations have soundtracks that relate to the culture of the people there.
The voice acting. What can I say but it is spot on. There is also humor blended throughout the voice acting. For example, when you run through crowds of NPCs and bump into them they make funny remarks or weird sounds.
There were some bugs in the game however. I have encountered a few with Roach running down hill but nothing was game-breaking or affecting my actual gameplay. These bugs were hilarious and added to the humor characteristic of the game to me.
Overall, I recommend trying out this game and even though you might be overloaded with the gameplay mechanics at first, just give it 2 hours. I am looking forward to what CD Projekt Red is doing for their future games.
