Witcher 3 is by far the best RPG game that I played. The story is so immersive that it won't let go until you complete the game. The world is interesting to explore as there is always something new that will be found.  Even the side quest are interesting to complete as there is no dull side quest in this game. Character development is wonderful as it introduces to every character even if you haven played previous games (or read books). Completed the game in 130 hours and still 2 DLCs left. The game is worth every cent you pay for it. Loved it from the very beginning to the very end.

This game is one of the best, if not THE BEST RPG I have ever played in my 20+ years of gaming. If you have not given this game a shot what are you even doing with your life? Very few if any game bugs, quests are great and meaty side quests are fun and not just simple fetch quests or kill count quests. Dialogue is great sound design and music choices are perfect.
All in all I would easily give this game a 10/10 well worth it and I can only hope CDPR gets it this right for Cyberpunk when it comes out later this year.

This game is my favorite game I've ever played, and one of the best games ever made. Every side quest is engaging, there are no fetch quests. The main story is very good, the graphics hold up very well, and it is an all round great game. The amount of content you are getting for $40 is absolutely insane. I would recommend this game to anyone who has even the slightest interest in RPGs.

One of the best RPG's I have ever played and a strong contender for first place, that's coming from someone who regards RPG's as their favourite genre since the PS1 era and has played most AAA RPG's released since the 2000's. The combat is complex but smooth and satisfying once you master it, I completed the game on death march(hardest difficults) with relative ease once I got going, not because it was easy, but the game rewards you for playing well and smart by not getting hit and exploiting enemy weaknesses by using signs(magic), potions and oils and good timing. The graphics are fantastic, the voice acting is fantastic, the story is fantastic, and aimed at a mature audience. There is SO much content to discover and the DLC's add dozens of hours more. I fell in love with the characters and the story so much I even bought the books. The only fault I can point out in this game is that there is SO much to do you can feel overwhelmed and get burnout. You can tell the developers poured their heart into this game and they did a fantastic job, well done CD Projekt.

A game so good I've brought it more than once (though still 20 short of Skyrim which should be released on my microwave soon).
The thing about the Witcher 3 which sets is apart from the rest is a level of craftsmanship in the world from the main quests, side quest, general world building and random encounters. For example, I was attach by some random bandits on horseback near Velen and I killed them with ease. Went ahead and looted their camp only to find a letter from one of the bandits to their wife which mentioned bringing something home for the young'un from their "da". It got me thinking and whilst a small addition to the game, it makes you think about how these bandits are people beyond simple video-game fodder.
Other endearing parts of the game are the easter eggs and callbacks to previous games (for those who played Witcher 1/2 like myself). If you've seen the Monty Python films, you might notice a certain conversation from beggars in Novigrad where one is complaining about being cured and it affecting their work.
Overall, one of my favourite games outside of the Mass Effect series and I'm really enjoying my current re-playthrough.

Some say that video games are an art form, people outside the industry are often quick to scoff at the idea. This game demonstrates that great video games are the definitive medium to tell the best stories. Movies and book have each their elegant charm but this game is something special, both the greatest book and the greatest movie ever created. All rolled in a living, evolving world that in the moment you can easily forget you aren't a part of. This was my first experience with the products of this developer. I will be spending 100s of dollars to make sure that I can be a part of the next one.

Best game of the decade

Never understood how a game could be "too long" until I played this game.
The sheer number of side quests the base game itself offers is insane, and of actually good quality, length, and story development, unlike most fetch quests games of this genre may usually suffer from. The main story itself is good too, though you'll likely find yourself ignoring the questline as exclamation points or question marks constantly pop up as you even make your way to the next destination. Before you know it, you've spent 2 hours on finishing side quests and contracts, and playing gwent alone.
Another thing that makes the story stand out is the fact that choices actually feel like they have impact in this game. Missing or ignoring certain side quests, or choosing bad options during the game can drastically affect the outcome of the game in terms of its lore (if you care about that). Also, you may miss out on certain gwent cards which is a massive rip. As such, you live with your decisions, something games for some reason find difficult to make work.
The overall environment looks beautiful and cutscenes, especially *certain* ones, are very well animated, making the game feel more immersive as a whole. The OST, characters, and "herbs schmerbs, but how 'bout some gwent" are great.
Also, have I mentioned to you how great gwent is?

The Witcher is as attractive as it is inelegant, immersive as it is clumsy, one of the best stories wrapped in one of the worse games ever.
The combat is completely unrewarding. There is no skill in this combat system. It's repeating simple patterns and damage adjustment based on level scaling.
The equipment is pointless. Your swords will be 10 levels past their prime for hours of gameplay. Run three witch bounties and you'll replace your original and two of the bounty sword rewards in 30 minutes.
The story doesn't care about how you play. There is no time or performance penalty. Racing an NPC? You're fine to stand around for 30 minutes then run through normally and win.
Don't even bother learning the combat system. Just dodge and fast attack, dodge and fast attack....
Even though one of the worst video games ever is standing in the way of the story and setting, it is still one of the best and immersive worlds. It is familiar, original, and delivers.

This game is definitely one of the best games I have ever played. The amount of care, detail, and attention put into everything is absurd. Every sidequest, even the most mundane ones, have charm and meaning to them. Every structure you find has a story behind it. All the enemies have unique and interesting designs and mechanics. The world is absolutely beautiful and is a wonderfully realistic and immersive setting. Novigrad is easily my favorite video game city of all time.
But I do not understand the unending praise this game gets.
Don't get me wrong. This game is absolutely fantastic. But this game is not a masterpiece. You hear this term just about everywhere, but it's a flawed gem. No game is perfect. Every game has problems. And the Witcher 3 has some annoying, hard to ignore problems.
The combat, for a game of this scale, is pretty great. It's clunky at first but you get a hang of it after a while. It's complete ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô?when fighting multiple enemies though. Those Wild Hunt Hounds are absolute hell to fight in packs. Hitboxes can be occasionally janky and enemy telegraphs aren't clear a lot of the time. The biggest problem with the combat, however, is that after a certain point it becomes way too easy. I was playing on the second highest difficulty and I was spam clicking just about every enemy without much trouble. The only things that challenged me were the three big bosses you face towards the end of the game. I really liked the feeling in the opening of the game where you had to prepare before a big fight. Brew a bunch of potions, buy food, temper your weapons, etc... and you do that for like 4 more levels and you don't have to anymore. Really wish that feeling was consistent throughout the game.
I find that the story loses some of its stride after the climax. It becomes a generic save the world plot - more about stopping the big bad than about developing characters or finding new interesting ones. There's really only three characters other than Geralt that see development during the final act. It's a real step down from when you were travelling across the Northern Realms, finding old and new friends, discovering their motivations, and watching them have actual character development. Just kinda stagnated towards the end. Also the ending is meh. Really could've used more explanation and there was some stuff that just... made no sense. The ending wasn't offensive, it was just 'whelming'.
I. Hate. The. Minimap. It's bad. Since nearly every single quest has a location objective where you have to travel somewhere through complex road systems (getting Roach through a forest or swamp is a pain in the ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô?so taking the roads are just easier), you have to heavily rely on the minimap's little dotted line telling you where to go. This is bad. You end up looking at the minimap 50% of the time. It's more difficult to immerse yourself in this beautiful world when you're not looking at it half the time. I turned off the minimap which greatly improved my experience, but I still had to open the map a lot to know where I'm going. It was pretty satisfying when in Novigrad I memorized the streets so I only had to glance at the map once or twice though.
I won't be going in depth about the pros of the game because I'm sure every review here will do that for you. I do still highly recommend this game. I'd say its a must-play.
One warning though: If you're looking to play a game that's about exploration first, story second, this ain't it. You'll still enjoy it but it won't be what you expect. The world is meant to be more of a realistic and immersive setting to the main story and the multitudes of sidequests there are. It's a different take on the world that I don't really mind. Breath of the Wild is still my favorite open world adventure game to date though.
P.S. kinda salty that this game stole all the rewards from Bloodborne in 2015 ngl

Hmmm... ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•.

At the time of this review, just a few months separate us from the fifth anniversary of The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt. The game has been called out by many to be the game of the decade, and I've decided to do a short no-spoilers retrospection on why is that the case. All of this coming from a player that hasn't even started his first NG+. PS.: I intended to keep this review short, but as I couldn't, I will include a TL;DR section below, targeted specifically to people that have not yet decided on whether to buy the game or not.
As you play as Geralt of Rivia, an already fleshed out character with its own personality and acquaintances right from the start, I would not dare call this game an RPG, but it is far simpler than saying that it is a "story driven action game with lots of decisions to make, some of which may have bigger or lesser impacts on the main story. Oh and you have lots of character progression, with various skill trees you can choose abilities from as well as lots of bombs, oils, potions, weapons and armor you can craft with materials you gather along your journey".
This RPG aspects of the game might drive out players that don't enjoy the genre, but it is very likely that they fall in love with any other aspect of the game. Aside from that, the game has four difficulties in total, and only the highest one REALLY demand you to make full use of these aspects to have an advantage; the other two allow you to have the upper hand whether you utilize the games' mechanics at full or not.
The combat is pretty basic, but it is very exciting and has a fluidity that makes up fully for its lack of depth. Combine that with any battle music track that the game rocks, and you will have an epic fight even against a simple drowner.
The music, as already foreseen, is simply amazing. I genuinely did not have any moment where I thought "hey this track is somewhat lackluster". Hell, there was this one time that I ended up humming 'Merchants of Novigrad' all day (for those who do not know, Novigrad is an important city of the game, and what I mentioned is an ambient music track played on said city). As I do not have any intricate thoughts on the matter, I beckon it will suffice to say that The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt stars one of the best soundtracks that I have ever listened to on a video game. Who woulda thunk.
Even though you play the role of an already built character with relationships of his own, the games' story and general narrative are incredibly enjoyable, not to mention that you still have a whole lot of decisions that build on Geralts' personality and make him a different character overall. Geralt is a really good main character, and he is one of the main reasons I keep playing the game. He's cool and interesting, his insights on various situations and his conversations with almost every character made me really want to flesh out his character and get to know his personality and relationships. The game has a large amount of secondary quests and contracts, and almost every change of track on your adventures rewards you something.
And we yet have to disclose graphics. The game was for me an INFINITELY immersing experience from the beginning. While you travel through the world you will encounter a lot, believe me, A LOT of incredibly beautiful places, landscapes and towns. I really recommend playing on High graphic settings, even at the expense of some frames if you don't have a high-end PC. Halfway through the game I just ramped up my settings just for the sake of even more beautiful landscapes, and at least for me, 50+ FPS is already an amazingly cinematic experience. Just the view from the balcony at Kaer Morhen on the very first scene of the game told me this was going to be a beautiful experience.
And it was just that. From joy to grief, from sadness to excitement, The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt made me feel a lot of different things. I really recommend that you play the game without spoiling yourself anything. The emotional spikes hit harder that way, and it really helps that you involve yourself on the narrative and on the characters' problems.
The only things I found to be issues to me were horse traveling, minor problems with the 'enemy upscaling' feature (on a certain djinn fight specifically), the underdeveloped character that was our main antagonist, and that the urgency of the main quest is not reflected on Geralts' journey (this, from my point of view, was inevitable, given the type of game the developers wanted to build, and the main quests' theme on the other side of the table). Two of those issues I cannot refer to due to my 'no-spoiler' disclosure, but they don't affect how the game feels AT ALL. And don't misinterpret me, the horse traveling isn't bad at all, in fact it is really good and it achieves its purpose. The only thing that bothered me were those moments where the horse randomly stopped while galloping, which lead me to just canter, and keep enjoying the scenery. A good thing overall, I guess.
TL;DR: TW3 is a must-try game. It goes really cheap for what it is on sales, and if it doesn't really hurt your pocket, then you must ABSOLUTELY try it. If it doesn't catch you when finishing the first act, then you can reconsider. If it is the RPG aspects that scare you, then believe me that they are not a big deal, specially on easier difficulties. They might even draw you into them as you play the game. TW3 rocks an amazingly good soundtrack, beautiful landscapes, and fluid combat. In this review I couldn't stress enough everything that I felt while playing the game, nor I was able to comment on every well done aspect the game has.
And that 'sums up' my experience. Please forgive my abuse of the same adjectives on multiple parts of the review, and my redacting skills. I didn't really intend to make it this long. If you have any recommendations, things to add or points to discuss, please feel free to leave a comment!

I have had literally NO, and I mean NO negatives with this game, it has been a TOTAL and COMPLETE joy to play, I can't recommend it enough, if you see this game on sale, DON'T let it pass you by, it's worth every penny of it's FULL price, so be sure to get it when you can!

This game isn't perfect. Still one of the best games I've ever played. The depth of every story is incredible, even in the scraps of paper you find on the side of a road. The quests are satisfying without exception, even when they're glorified fetch missions, simply because the dialogue is so engaging.
Combat is quite simple, but never feels boring. Getting new potions, oils and decoctions feels rewarding. The skill trees have their flaws (some early game perks are broken, some late game perks are terrible), but overall make it feel worthwhile to try different builds for the fun of it (even on the hardest difficulty, nothing is brutally challenging without mods).
Recommended for anyone who likes a very intricate story where most of your decisions, no matter how large or small, have an impact. Fans of series like KOTR will adore this game.

A very gripping story, especially for those familiar with Sapkowski's stories and novels. Very variable quests all through the game, you never get the feeling of "just another boring monster slaying, herb collecting" or whatnot. The only tiny flaw might be the character development system, stat/attribute/combat bonus display system and random item generation system which are simply wanting, even though relatively elegant at the same time. But combat itself, along with all the various animations, is simply fluid and beautiful, especially on harder difficulties it is challenging all the way through the game. And the graphics is stunning for now several-years-old game.
All in all, I must repeat what I had been told before I purchased the game on numerous occasions - a TRUE must-have for all fans of RPG genre and much recommended even to those who only play such games on special occasions.
And by the way, the built-in collectible card game of gwent is in itself a masterpiece in simplicity and elegance.

People call this the best RPG/Open world game ever created, I think that's overrating this game. Personally I prefer the first 2 games in the series since they followed a non-linear "act" based format instead of Open World.
It's already been said a million times but the graphics, writing, sound, music are great. So I won't go deep into that.
The locations and visuals are a downgrade from Witcher 2. I mean go back to Flotsam Forest in W2 and then back into W3's "Trees and a random copy paste village in between open world"
It does suffer a bit from Ubisoft syndrome where there's a lot of copy and paste activities sprinkled around the map but they can be easily ignored if you want and it's best to focus on side quests and Witcher contracts. The weakest quest types are usually treasure/scavenger hunts.
Crafting/Alchemy is still under developed and bloated. On the bright side, the game is incredibly long to support them this time, since Witcher 2 was 20-30 hours long. The movement, animations, horse controls etc are really average compared to most third person games.  The Combat is a slightly improved Witcher 2, never has and never will be great.
Trust me for someone who has played the first and the second games for over a decade, the series has always been carried by it's storyline, characters and writing. The Witcher has always been a gloried walking simulator and I'm okay with that. Yennifer, Bloody Baron, The Crones and Ciri are the highlights here.
The games first part which takes place in Velen is some of the best stuff I've seen in the series. However, once you reach Novigrad you'll experience what I found to be the weakest part of the game. The problem is the whole Dandelion part being dragged on probably even breaking the record for way too many fetch quests. Considering the game has another island to explore after that, you could get burned out especially if you're unfamiliar with the first 2 games. Also the whole "roleplaying" and choice making doesn't seem to effect you drastically in this game beyond choosing how big of a prick you want Geralt to be.
The weakest part of the entire game though is Eredin and everything to do with the Wild Hunt. Three freaking games for it to play out this way? Why did he have to take off his mask? Yes Letho and Geralt talk about the Wild Hunt being Aen Elle but I would have preferred if they still maintained some kind of mystic around him. I remember being excited back in 2007 and not being familiar with the books thinking that the Wild Hunt was going to be a rendition of the myth of the dead army that roams across the sky.
Game is incredibly long, being an open world game, the 80% of your playtime will be you getting from point A to Point B. I enjoyed it but actually did see myself getting burned out by the time I finished the main story, Heart Of Stone and it's sidequests to move on to Blood and Wine which takes place in Toussaint.
My recommendation is to play Blood and Wine after taking a break from finishing Main game and HOS. Heart Of Stone is the second highlight of the game, first being the Baron/Crones questline. Another highlight is Gwent being far better than dice as a minigame this time around.
Verdict: While I think the third game is probably the weakest, and the series never managed to get combat/crafting right it's a great end to one of my favourite game trilogies.

The Witcher 3 has something for every RPG fangirl/boy, and it's polished just about every feature with a Blizzard level of sheen.

Though I find the combat to be more stiff than Assassin's Creed Odyssey, it's still a blast. It's so well designed with the dodging, rolling and blocking. With the differing styles of fighting monsters and humans it's no wonder that at over 100 hours (Counting my time on Xbox One) I have not gotten bored of it. Great game, vast, open world, so much to do and beautiful! I'm on my 2nd play-through now, trying to unlock the secrets of this world that I basically skipped over in the first run-through. I did pretty much the main story the first time around, some side quests. This time, I'm running through trying to do things differently. You make certain choices in the game that affect future events and I'm trying to make different choices this time to see how the game ends. But I'm mainly focusing on unlocking the map, exploring EVERYTHING and taking advantage of the full game. I'm 119 hours in and I'm only 3/4th the way through the 2nd area lol. It's addicting, fun, thrilling, keeps you coming back day after day and I would highlly recommend it. I tried witcher 2, it was awful as far as the way it's laid out; the witcher 3 is definitely far and away a much better game and it's replayable over and over again, which makes it a great purchase. If you love fantasy, role playing, open world concepts, lore, and a TON of stuff to do, this is the game for you.

Did you ever hear the tragedy of Darth Plagueis The Wise?
I thought not. It's not a story the Jedi would tell you. It's a Sith legend. Darth Plagueis was a Dark Lord of the Sith, so powerful and so wise he could use the Force to influence the midichlorians to create life‚Ä?He had such a knowledge of the dark side, he could even keep the ones he cared about from dying.
The dark side of the Force is a pathway to many abilities some consider to be unnatural.
He became so powerful‚Ä?the only thing he was afraid of was losing his power, which eventually, of course, he did. Unfortunately, he taught his apprentice everything he knew, then his apprentice killed him in his sleep. Ironic. He could save others from death, but not himself.

Witcher 3, in my opinion, is the greatest open-world RPG of all time - the only equal being Red Dead Redemption 2. As someone who plays games for story and immersion, there is no equal in the fantasy genre besides maybe Skyrim (coming in at a VERY close second). Rich lore, realistic characters and riveting monster slaying (human and nonhuman alike) make the Witcher 3 a timeless classic worth losing yourself in for hours on end. If you're a fan of fantasy, RPGs, open-world games or all three and you haven't played Witcher 3, you're missing out on the experience of a lifetime.

I like many others put in a few hours when I originally purchased the GotY edition on steam before dropping it due to boredom. Also like many others, I picked it up again after The Witcher Netflix series sparked my interest again. This time I downloaded a few QoL and texture mods before going along my marry way. The story can be good at times, but also cliched and boring many other times. It's hard to put into words but there isn't any immediate thrill in terms of exploring the world, and the monotonous quests don't help with that.
If you're not collecting bounties then you're using your witcher senses to be Sherlock Holmes, and that gets rather repetitive after some time. The combat also felt really boring and unimaginative. You have all sorts of weapons at your disposal such as bombs, crossbows, swords, and magic, and each enemy has weaknesses for you to take advantage of but I rarely found myself using these tools. Maybe on harder difficulties there's more emphasis on using oils and other things, but I don't know how much more difficult you can make the game when all you really need to do is learn when to parry/dodge/roll.
I enjoyed the story in the beginning, but by the time I got to Skellige I was skipping through dialogue to just try and wrap the game up before my boredom made me drop it again. The ending was lackluster and predictable, and there's a NG+ option but I'm not sure if I have the drive to go through it all again. For now I'll be trying the DLC's.

Bought this game for the low price of $16 CAD on sale. At the time of writing this review I am still to finish the game, but so far everything I have done has been interesting. The combat here is fairly good, there is a large variety of monsters to encounter that always offer something a little different. The graphics and optimization for me are astounding, 60 FPS on almost everything ultra with a decent PC. Loading times are extremely quick for me which allows for minimal downtime when starting or fast travelling. The multiple free DLC's add some nice things to be enjoyed (alternate looks, different finishers, ect). Lastly Gwent, this card game that you can play with NPC's offers the ability to be able to take a break from the main game and just play cards. The side quest associated with Gwent is fun to go through. All in all this is an extremely good game in my opinion, worth it at full price, on sale it's a no brainer. 9/10.

The graphics are sick, would never say it's a 2015 game if you asked me. The combat system is great. The story though... that one's fantastic, bold and underlined fantastic. A lot of tough choices that make you really think about it. You have a say in almost every decision, and you've no idea how it's gonna impact your future, you can only do what you feel is right at the time.
The DLC's: When I had finished Heart of Stone, I thought
was a great DLC with a lot of content and story, and was the better of the two. Boy was I in for a treat with Blood and Wine then. That blew me away. From a doom and gloom type of setting and swampy or snowy biomes you go into a world of eternal summer and sunshine. Sometimes I wish the whole game had the atmoshphere of Toussaint.
recommend getting the DLC's. Both of them. (though if you really must choose, I'd get Blood and Wine).
If you still haven't played the game, and like story driven RPGs with a bunch of content and decisions, get the game with all the expansions, and I *guarantee* - you will
it.
immersion.

This game is wonderful, best game I've ever played hands down.
It's everything so rich in details, the developers clearly though every inch of the world and mande it full of life. That creates a worthy and remarkable experience. Plus the system of choice makes you carry a sense of consequence at every corner. There were choices I regreted the whole game, and that's the cool of it.
I played at hard difficulty (Blood and Broken Bones!) and can say that the gameplay is set so the game won't forgive many mistakes. Even enemy 10 lvls below yours can make significant damage. Also, populating the world with sidequests and locals with creatures of different lvls makes up for desperate escapes when you face iminent death. And that's a brilliant scale up, as you'll always have stuff to do.  I chose to do every side mission of the game. Finished base game in 110 hours. Another 40 hours for DLCs.
There's so much that add to the gameplay, to the overall experience, that is quite remarkable how they balanced the game. Looting, crafting, alchemy, signs, oils, potions, bombs, guns, merchants and money, they even created their own card game FFS (Gwent). Also, creating a vast variety of creatures and enriching the lore with the bestiary and a journal entry for each character. That's a hell of a work, props to CD Project Red. Granted, I only played this game 4 years after release, they could make some tweaking but I got to experience a masterpiece.
When I entered DLC territory I decided to add some mods to enhance the experience and god was that a right move. I did not altered gameplay in any means, only added quality to visuals and quality of life improvements. But going through the mods list I was delighted of how much of a new experience can one get from the game by adding mods. There are even those that completely rehauls the entire gameplay, rebalancing everything, and makes up for a better and more daring/challenging walkthrough. And all that with a great concern of maintaining the lore. Mod community clearly expands a game's life. I can definetely see myself coming back for a replay with a different approach.
I was not able to drag myself through the first two games (shame) as it is too dated and clunky for my taste but before entering the 3rd I watched videos carefuly explaining the story and boy was I hyped to start. Don't know if the books could provide as much enjoyment as this game (I'll definetely read at a later time), which has cemented itself as a GOAT for a lot of people. Long live their creators.

This is a review for the base game only.  If you like Skyrim, get this.  It improves on it for the most part. Fantastic side quest stories and characterization is top notch.  Better than any game I have ever played.
Pros:
Great graphics
Great writing.  On the side quests in particular. Does not feel like busy work.  Interesting stuff
Music is atmospheric though repetitive
Immersive open world
Neutral
Combat.  Better than skyrim but not as engaging as it  could be although I beat it only on normal so maybe it is more interesting on higher difficulties. Feels a bit spammy with the potion gimmick
Cons
Story ending was disappointing.  Lots of dangling threads and the ending was shorter than some sidequest cutscenes.
Clunky interface which is not much better than the skyrim one.  If you didn't mind Skyrim then this should be okay,
Taking money only for food

AMAZING game. I am a witcher fanatic i also played and completed previous games, I think the plot will be more concrete in your head if you also play (or at least know) the plot of 1st and 2nd game. However, for my general view, i am already caught up for the plot so I would say the plot is tastefully complex, the  main characters have depth and personalities, and your choices in the game are actually matter (pretty much unlike the telltale games lol) . The additions of various contracts/ suprize exclamation mark quests / treasure hunts the context quality of gameplay is pretty advance and extended, I would say. I am actually up to 123 H of gameplay (I was offline most of the time) and i still didnt finish it, sometimes i just open the game and walk around the game doing nothing. (I'll give my reasoning below)
Other than these, I never encountered with any bugs, no opening problems, the game's dynamics is pretty much  flowing and waiting time is fast for me.
In short, I really enjoyed the game and maybe this one is #1 game of my list. My absolute favorite. I definitely recommend everyone at least try their chance with this series.  (not just because I am in love with geralt. but for the reasons here lol)
(spoilers ahead)
I'll start with what I really like, which is the small details, for example(one of my favorite moments), i did choose the comedy option for the theater that was so good, quite later on in the game, while i was casually walking on the streets of novidgrad, a random elderly women said that she liƒ±ked my performance there and laughed outloud.  This moment gave me the feeling of realism, and made me forget i am in a game and those were NPC's. I started to look at them as real persons inside the game instead of npc's, especially if you are a slow-player and you like to stop and listen what people say. The immersive environment made me feel like i really lived in that middle age surreal world maybe because I also played the game with ultra settƒ±ngs 60 fps rtx. This game becomes superb when you install HD mod ,  i literally stopped per every 30 seconds to look at the environment and beautiful designs of every object.
The critiques: I would expect more skins/different clothes etc. I really like fashion in a game alot and i spend money for outfits not armors or swords lol
even though there are many monsters, I would expect more varƒ±ous monster types (because it becomes repetitive after a while) . Fiends looking the same, bears are same, vampires are same, trolls are the same. What i want different types more interesting ones, for example make gargoyles more like gargoyles not like trolls.  OR More collossal ones. For example i really liked the Kayran quest in witcher 2. There was no such foe until now in W3.
Also i really would appreciate more blood, more gore and more realistic blood.
Also
please bring an dlc to fix Yennefer / triss triangle please because i really love two of them at the same time. I cannot choose one over another, no matter how much i try. Polyamory exists sooo maybe you can do something about this.
Thank you,
Best regards

Came for the raunchy sex scenes that I was going to fap to.
Stayed for the breathtaking sceneries, the mesmerizing sunrise and sunset, the vast fields of flowers, the peaceful villages along the way that dare not venture out after dark in fear of unnamed horrors, the darkest nights into the woods with only that silvery light of the moon above my head, the realistic windy forests and the rains... a fantasy world that I thought I could only see when reading folklore stories back then... a world that is so alive, a world that I can never be bored of returning to...
Well, all that, and the witty conversations, the heart-wrenching moments when I had to make choices that I know could never be easy, that no choice could be a lesser evil, the characters that lived with you, stayed with you and died with you along the way with every choice you made, and you know for sure that they will live within your memories forever... the monsters, the ghosts that you almost feel sorry for them... for their stories are so sad, so bitter and make you wonder do they really deserve the end of my silver sword...
Oh well my friends, forget the fapping, this is a masterpiece that is gonna stay with you for a lifetime.

This is a very extensive RPG with phenomenal mature story telling. Plenty to explore, a plethora of side quests and a decently long main story, dialogue, time wasting, card games, (Gwent.)
You'll see a lot of visual and dialogue relating to war, the hardships of war, the victims, the butchered, the great and unjust crimes.
You will heavily explore Geralt being treated as an inferior being because he is a Witcher and not a Human.
I definitely agree with the games popularity and understand why so will add another voice to its success and recommendation.
Adding on to the main game is the expansions and excellent list of free content including some extra contracts.
Combat is extensive in regards to abimltiies, armor, weapons, potions, bombs, magic signs, horse combat.
People say the game has clunky controls, I agree to a small extent, still extremely modern and playable. Roach, (your horse,) is fairly doping, has some really odd pathing amd it is preferable to fast travel because Roach can't stick to the correct path, (or any,) quite often and he is not fond of bridges crashing to a halt.
I think the earliest and also best example of the mature story telling is the story of the Bloody Baron and his family. It covers a myriad of social issues from alcoholism, to family violence, to death, children, a fathers love, a fathers agony of mistakes, loss, love.
Gwent - to begin with the game comes with its own in game card game, Gwent. It is a very simple and surprisingly fun thing to play and will leave you ignoring the story for many hours.
Horse racing - There are quite a few horse races to compete in, put money in, gain renown and vs better riders etc.
Boxing - there are boxing tournaments with varying degrees of difficulty
The map exploration is just filled with towns, cities, caves, interesting sights, endless horse riding, yacht driving, item gathering, dialogue, sights, enemies, wild animals, magical creatures, side quests, small hilarious, sad or crazy happenings. There are many [?] locations to be revealed when you explore them. You can track bounties, find treasure, formulate alchemy, find treasure hunts, letters, Witcher gear, lore and back story and a very many chances to make many minor, petty and main quest or side quest changing decisions, such as throw fights to help a poor farmer, kill mercilessly, hand people in, hand out justice, be greedy, get paid off. You get the chance to disrespect a king born to be revered, have romantic relationships with various women, (I'm early on and so far it is flirting with Truss alongside your "relationship" with Yennefer.) There are some heart breaking endings to some characters lives too that will wrench at your soul, disappoint you, you'll be in control or the main antagonist behind some deaths, you will fight the Wild Hunt, (another version of the walking dead from Game of Thrones, regarding the White Walker leaders.)
There's definitely a lot more to touch on, but this game, it is just phenomenal mature RPG story telling that really works.
You're really missing out by not atleast trying this game out. I'd say a good serving of this game is atleast until you get out of Velen, into Novigrad.
White Orchard servers as a very small starting area for players too, it shows many different aspects of play, introduces Gwent, the main story, contracts, side quests, treasure, Witcher gear, alchemy, using alchemy against different monsters/beasts/magik.
There are so many thousands of positive reviews for this game, if you've read this far and like the sound of it, definitely pick this long, content filled mature RPG up! It is a complete 10/10 thumbs up for me and the horse stuck on my roof says get it too.
I've had a small serving and I want the whole main course. You will too.

9 Hours into the game, and so far it is enjoyable.
I should warn you, it is very standard for Open World RPG Games. There is a main quest, which involves going from place to place, meeting NPCs, and solving their fetch or kill quests. With as much of it as I have played, it is really average storytelling. Nothing really groundbreaking.
However, it also has a metric ton of side-quests. These really flesh out the world and give you a good sense of the story, and the world in which the story inhabits. This is, at least at only 9 hours into the game, the real reason to play this game.
Gamplay? Oh? That? You swing a big sword. Throw some spells. There is a fair amount of alchemy. Your horse is fun to ride. Kill-loot-sell-buy-upgrade-kill-loot-sell-upgrade-you-know-the-drill. But it is at least as of this time, an enjoyable loop.
Graphics are top notch. Definitely a lot of work went into that. Especially the environmental effects. Some of the storms you can almost feel.
Sound Effects? Do you remember when Blizzard was King of the sound effects with Diablo II? Well, this is better than they ever were. These sounds are part of what makes the environment so believable.
Music? No clue. I always turn that off.
My premature thoughts? This is a good game worth playing, if you are into Open World Fantasy RPGs.
But, if it does a dive near the end like MGS5:PP did, do not blame me, I have not finished it yet.

If you're here after watching the show and wondering if the game is as good, the answer is a resounding yes. The game is even better. From the main quests down to the smallest of side quests, everything is incredibly well written and unique. This version of Geralt is just as badass as Henry Cavill's. It's also technically a sequel so events from the show will be referenced, and some storylines are even continued. If you're worried about needing to play the previous two games, don't be. It's really not that necessary. I didn't play the previous games and I was never lost in the slightest. The gameplay is phenomenal as well. Lighting people on fire feels just good as parrying someone and chopping their head off. You can customize your own playstyle with a lengthy and in depth skill tree to make your Geralt truly unique. To top it all off, there is ridiculous mod support for it. It's also super easy if you've never modded anything before. I've never modded a game before this and I was able to streamline my experience a significant amount with a few simple mods. Considering all of that, the only real question is: Why the ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• are you still reading reviews? Buy this ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing game already.

The mods for this game very from redesigning armor sets like the Griffin set (cause it REALLY needs it) too weather, climate and millions of others to choose from. I've only just started modding it so if anyone's got some suggestions please feel free to comment them. But to end the review off I'd say, GET THIS GAME. This is worth the money all of its flaws included.

You really have to pay attention to the dialogue or miss hints on the best decisions to make.  Very little is black and white in this game.  The graphics, scenery, music, voice acting and character design are all top notch too.  Sometimes I just like to ride or sail around looking at things.  I've sunk well over 100 hrs into the game and it still surprises me.  I feel like I've barely scratched the surface.

Ok, On default settings this game looks ATROCIOUS. When I say default I mean everything maxed on Ultra.
Here is what you switch off, So you stop getting eyestrain and it doesn't look like someone regurgitated a bucket of pixels.
Motion Blur: OFF
Blur: OFF
AA (blur AA it looks like not real): OFF
Foliage density: LOWEST
Vignetting: OFF
Chromatic Aberation: OFF (this is an optical defect of lenses, Why the f*ck would anyone think it looks good?)
It looks like the max FPS is 60 until you slide it backwards/lower to "Unlimited"
At that point, This game stopping making my eyes bleed and my ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• leak (side effect of bleeding eyes).
For $17 after doing all that this is a steal.

I write this review having finished the main story line, without having started the two expansions. As a fan of the first two games and RPGs in general I absolutely love this game and highly suggest it to anyone who enjoys a good RPG. My biggest suggestion actually comes from a friend who played it and that's to focus on the main story, and do side quests that appear along your way. I wasn't expecting the game to be near as long so I focused solely on side quests for a while and ended up reaching and spoiling areas that the story would later take me to. Here's a list of the good and bad I found with it:
Gwent!! The mini card game is a nice change of pace from the dice poker and easily one of the funnest things about the game.
The shear size of the world and the various ways to get around. The world is huge, Skyrim if not bigger size, and it has ways for you to travel quickly but spaces them out so you can experience some of the little moments you would miss if you did nothing but jump from spot to spot.
Inventory in this one was handled very well, along with equipment/crafting being the best out of the three games in my opinion.
The story was well balanced, and paced in my opinion. Better than the first game in that it didn't feel rushed anywhere but not quite as good as the second....I think primarily it felt dragged out in spots.
The characters, not just the main ones but all of the npcs and the random dialogue you got to listen in on as you walked about.
The length of the game. Don't get me wrong its worth your money, my 200 hours was my first play through without the expansions, so there's no lack of good content. It just feels like at times that they could have broken it up into smaller games, where it would have been easier to keep track of all that was going on rather than having such a long and multiple thread story.
The Character tree feels disconnected from the game. It's not hard to understand by any means but I honestly didn't feel any difference in ability as I leveled up. It's not like the first two games where I could tell a difference each time I gained a level and added new abilities. Personally I saw more change through equipment than anything else.
The loading recap of the story. Its nice when you girst boot up the game but then if you choose to load your game it replays it again. There were times I would go through several loads to try different things and it got very tiring hearing it every time I loaded.
The text font/color during cut scenes. It's great for not distracting from the scene but when you had the timed reactions it felt like I never had enough time to fully read my options. I've never been a big fan of timed respones but at least make the choices easier to read.

The best RPG I have ever played. The story telling is immersive and the world feels alive. There are no parts of the game that I think are even mediocre. The combat takes some getting used to, but once learned is rewarding and makes you feel so skilled. Would have to give it a 10/10. Skyrim is nostalgic but lame compared to this game.

Such a fun game, the combat is fluid and complex enough without being overwhelming, you can button mash your way through or play with strategy and take no damage and save resources. Graphics are great and have aged well to date, the audio is well put together and I like the soundtrack.
Voicing/dialogue is okay - some issues with it but generally immersive and true to the world

Story - Excellent with great depth and a fascinating feel of realism regardless of the fantasy setting. A grim and dark setting that still manages a humanity that staves off any disregard the player might otherwise have for character direction and choices.
Game play - A decent amount of variable game play considering you can only play as a character with a two handed sword. Combat feels rewarding and makes you feel like you are the well trained Witcher you are playing as. However, depending on your control device it can also be frustrating. The 3rd person view didn't track well with my controller sometimes leading me to blind movements that were not always conducive to Geralt's continued health and wellness. I played almost my entire time on a steam controller. I also have briefly tried mouse and keyboard which seemed very clunky considering how smooth Geralt is meant to fight and transition between tactics during battles.

I've always been too afraid of how low my skill is in gaming, but with a few mods I began to play this game with the difficulty way down. The story, the characters, the world is all absolutely incredible, and it has ignited a passion for open world RPGs and inspired me to read the books and play the previous game too. I am playing through New Game + without the difficulty mods now, and I cannot thank CD Projekt Red enough for creating a game whose lore and detail urged me to push past the fear of being terrible at video games. The choice, the consequence, the delicately interwoven story, it is all awe inspiring!

This game truly is a work of art.
Normally, I'd stick to competitive multiplayer games or at least difficult games like dark souls. I'm someone who strives to master some sort of ability when playing games. However, the Witcher 3 makes an exception. Of course, there are plenty of things to be learned, but it doesn't have the depth when it comes to the actual combat-system, which feels rather monotone. This of course is just my opinion and I'm sure there are many arguments to be made against it, especially since there are far worse games out there.
I love this game for the stories, quests and the writing of almost all characters which sets a new standard when it comes to videogames. It's basically the only one, in which I don't skip the dialog, even on my second playthrough. It's just that well written and I love the voiceacting.
Without going into further details, the game is great and considering the value for money - especially on sales -, there is almost no reason not to own it. This doesn't mean it's without flaw. For example, as I already mentioned, the combat-system, which made me stop my first playthrough for more then a year because I got bored of it (I started watching let's plays instead, and yes, it's actually a perfect match). On my second playthrough I modded the combat with ghost mode, which makes it far more interesting, at least for me personally and the difficulty can further be adjusted.
Don't get misled by my steam-playtime, it's just a fraction of my actual playtime.

I never really got to enjoy this game as it came out, and picked it up again in 2019.
I am now in my second playthrough (new game+) and have sunken 196 hours into it, and I'm still not fed up with it.
This game ages gracefully - Although there are still a few pretty mind boggling bugs remaining in the game in some quest lines. Some game mechanics will feel off or "old" at times (like Geralts less than precise movement outside combat), but the game itself, it's story and EVEN Gwent (Just give it a shot. It's not that complicated) is very entertaining.
The expansions are really well made - And Blood and Wine (the second and final big DLC), if it was published or made by lesser men - Would have been a separate game; cause it has a completely different feel to it, lasts longer than expected and brings a whole bunch of new stuff to the game and at the same time adds more polished animations, cut scenes and dialogue.
As long as you are prepared to use the quick save-feature generously, you will have a good time.

It's a good game but wildly overrated. I've put a few dozen hours into it, haven't enjoyed it at all. I'll probably finish it for the sake of completing the story.
There are 2 things that ruin this game for me. First, the writing. Second, the level zones. The game is heavily story-focused, but all of the quests and locations have level zones like in an MMO. That means (despite all the talk about "choices matter") there's really only one way to play through the narrative. And if you don't go that route, then you'll be facing Drowners that are 10 levels above you and take 20 minutes to kill. You CAN kill them (that's how easy the game is)... it's just going to take forever and be really boring.
My other complaint is the writing. I don't know why everyone says this is such a well-written game. It's not. The writing isn't bad in a technical way, it's bad in a creative way. The Witcher's world is too bleak and hopeless to be believable. Almost everyone is a terrible person, and everyone seems okay with that. One king commits incest, another fantasizes about torture. There's a prostitute on every street corner, and the only representation of religion in the game is a fanatical cult of witch-burning monotheists. *Rolls eyes at thinly veiled Catholic Inquisition reference*.
The result of this design choice is that the characters just don't talk like real people. The game keeps shoving selfish pessimists and suffering wretches into your face, demanding that you accept the total lack of goodness as realistic. Characters keep telling you how bad things are. They try to show you how "dark & gritty" they are by swearing a lot and making ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• jokes. Even the kings & nobleman act like this, and it's really unnatural. I mean, when was the last time the Queen of England made a ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• joke then bragged about torturing her enemies? People just don't TALK this way. Not everyone, at least. And not all of the time.
At 20 hours in, I was wondering "doesn't anyone ever smile in this world?" Turns out, somebody did. Then that somebody mutilated a prostitute's corpse, hung it from his ceiling, and begged me not to gut him. I gutted him anyway. And now, I'm sitting in front of my PC rolling my eyes at how badly this game wants to think of itself as "mature".
Also, the voice acting is inconsistent. Accents don't make sense. For some reason, every dwarf has the same Scottish accent as the Skellige Islanders do... despite the fact that not once did I see a dwarf in Skellige. Meanwhile, all the Novigrad people are Cockney (except for the nobles, whose accent is "posh & gay"). But then there are people who've seemingly lived their whole lives in that city and have an American accent. Not to mention Geralt himself, who whisper-growls everything like Batman and sounds like he came from San Diego.
Geralt's character is clumsily developed at times. It's hard to buy into his eternal love for Yennefer (or Triss) when he's hanging out with Dandelion reminiscing about orgies, or when he's buying some poor Cockney girl in one of the many, many brothels. (Actually, all of the prostitutes in this game are 100% okay with being prostitutes. It's a lifestyle choice, and they demand you respect it.) Anyway, it's an awkward contrast.
The writing is also oddly political for a game set in medieval times. The entire Novigrad story arc is "Geralt helps his SJW waifu protect immigrants from crazed religious bigots." It's a weird questline. And really unbalanced. There's a very clear "good side" and "bad side", with no nuance at all. You either stop the bigots from murdering cross-dressing elves, or you're a terrible person and Triss hates you. Then, there's Yennefer's bizarre speech comparing prohibitions against necromancy to prohibitions against premarital sex‚Äîthey're both "outdated". Yes, she actually says that. Considering no one else in the game EVER condemns casual sex, it's a really weird comparison. Like, who ARE these mysterious sex-haters? Where are they? They can't be a religious group, the only religion is the crazed elf-murdering cult and they LOVE the brothels.
So yea, the writing and leveling made this game a solid 6/10 for me.

Witcher 3 is the best RPG I've ever played, and possibly the best GAME I've ever played. It has a great story that will lead you on a wild journey across one of the largest maps I have played on. The art and graphics are amazing, and the music really sets the mood, whether you are battling a pack of drowners, or flirting with the "ladies" in a brothel. I am running an old Alienware Aurora R7 with a GTX 1070 that I picked up about 2 years ago, and I can run everything on ultra-high, and the environment is (again) one of the best I have played in.
I won't keep going, because I am already beginning to sound like a broken record. It's not perfect... Sometimes a body will continue to ragdoll down a gentle slope when it should have stopped immediately. Today I walked into a nice, warm, cozy house, just to find that it was raining inside, even though it had a perfectly good roof. Riding your horse, Roach, is so awkward that I just run everywhere. A lot of people complain about the combat, but I like it just fine. However, I'm a 44 year old fart that uses a keyboard and mouse, instead of a controller, and I just can't keep up with the 12 year olds anymore. There are also hundreds of mods out there to change any aspect of the game you wish but, I have not used any of them to date so I cannot comment on their usefulness.
Overall, it is extraordinarily immersive and a must-have for single-player RPG fans. I'd give it a 9.7/10, and I am demanding from my games, so many would consider that score fairly harsh. In my opinion, there are just some things that should have been fixed before it was released. I have seen other reviewers say that they were not paid for their review, and since I know how to spell and use fairly proper English, I guess I will say that I was NOT paid for mine either (although I wouldn't mind knowing how that works:)).

I recently ended the game, is like missing something, i... dont know what to say, for the first minutes to the last from White Orchad to Velen, Novigrad to Skellige (lovely smugglers caches, ill miss them), and then Toussaint, this is not a game, is a experience, managing to play with your thoughts, yourself, your sentiments, making you stand up, go around so you can think what to ask the correct question, say the correct answer, choose the right decision, how they created a world so alive, a crew of so lovely charaters, except Radovid, die ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô?prck, i prefer Eredin over you XD, i suffered for several panic attacks after my not so nice last semester of the year in collegue, i have serious emotional issues, and this game made me feel happy, calm, looking at the world i created in this universe im so happy that i have to confess my sins, i... in 2016 cracked this game... i didnt think CDPR deserved, i was in so much hate against the game industry that i went into a piranting rampage, in fact i didnt have money to buy anything to be perfectly honest, i played the game... in i regretted stealing the game, and as a punishment i bet, i got the worst ending, the worst, i was so mad and so sad, broken even that i cried so much hahaha, i said, no, i refuse i will quit the game, deinstall it and wait to gather enough money to buy it, so i did then i played... i got the best endings in both the base game and the expansions, please for what we hold dear, play this game, swim in the tides of story, thank you CDPR, Thank You so much, looking foward to the next adventure

I doubt I'll be able to say anything that hasn't been said before, but even five years after release, I'm still coming back to this game and consider it to be one of the best I've ever played.
Yes, it's starting to show it's age, and even when it first came out it had some jank (Roach, I'm lookin' at you...) but it's still a well-written, enjoyable game. Even now, on my third-plus playthrough, I'm noticing things I never noticed before, or making realizations that I missed on earlier playthroughs. There's a lot of depth to the world and the storytelling, that just gets richer with each playthrough.
The world is extremely well fleshed-out, and even though the Witcher is based off a series of fantasy novels, I believe the game has far surpassed the source material in terms of world building and character development. Even if you don't enjoy the gameplay or are having trouble with the combat, I would recommend completing this game on an easier difficulty if only to enjoy the rich storytelling.

This game is amazing. I aint gonna lie, it is not perfect, but it is a delight, reminds me of the good old Gothic games. It has limits in the role playing aspect, as you are a set character, but it sure as hell compensates with an intresting plot and well written characters. Combat is not best ever, but i even liked the gothic style, and that was utter garbage. The good, the game is dripping with atmosohere, the graphics are absolutely satisfying. The artistist and designers delivered a believable world, that is fierce, unsettling, but can be absolutely beautyful at times. The more you take away from the UI/HUD the more you will appriciate the game world. It could be improved im sure, and i hope CDPRed will improve it with time, but this is a great game already. Totally worth my money.

Toss A Coin To Your Witcher
This is the best RPG ever made. Not kidding. Yes. Still.

Shorter TL:DR ‚Ä?
TL:DR
If you're like me and saw The Witcher's Netflix series and felt the need to boot up this beauty once more, welcome!
I've followed with A LOT of interest The Witcher 3 and partially the second entry in the franchise. Never had the PC to run this game and now I jumped to that chance and I'm so glad I did.
In a matter of weeks (1.5 to be exact) this game caught my attention, passion, sweat and tears, keeping me glued to the screen for well over 14 hours at times in one day thanks to its characters, quests, sidequests and just incredibly stunning world. It's just phenomenal.
I've known The Witcher saga for quite a while, played the first one well over a decade ago, just a couple of hours, but that was enough to keep me interested and that led to me spending quite a large amount of time watching playthroughs, story recaps, hell even memes about The Witcher's universe.
I finally managed to get myself a nice GOTY edition for this game and with a bunch of tweaks managed to get it running at a sort of stable 15-20 FPS (yup, PC Masterrace  member here), definitely playable, not enjoyable but playable.
Let's go for the traditional review now, I bored you enough with pointless details.
The Witcher games are based on the books, the stories take place after the events in the books. There will be near constant references to characters that appeared in both books and previous entries in The Witcher 3 (as expected) which will be overwhelming. Therefore I suggest watching some recap of the books and the games, if you really don't wanna spend a good 200+ hours on the games plus all the books.
You're playing as Geralt of Rivia, the White One, Butcher of Blaviken, Mutant, Freak, Sorceresses ...ehm, lover. You'll hear his name 12 times a minute,so don't worry, you won't forget it.
You're a badass witcher, strong mutated group of humans that, to put it as bluntly and as simply as possible, they are mercenaries that follow a moral code and the highest bidder, for both men and beasts.
The story is a pretty nice and long one, with a ton of characters, most of them likeable
that feel real, deep. You can see them change thanks or because of your actions, for the better or worse. Especially with the closer ones
you'll start feeling a connection, something that rarely happened in an RPG game to me before.
There's a lot of sidequests, and I mean a LOT of SIDEquests. There's plenty of games that call sidequests absolutely pointless quests that don't progress the story in anyway whatsoever, such as Skyrim, with simple, boring and repetitive fetch quests. Sadly
, but some are far more entertaining and memorable than others.
Some are contracts that you pick up in game, they're simple ‚ÄúGo to X, kill Z, go back to Y for reward‚Ä? some are what would be considered main quests in many other RPGs, with full cutscenes, actual story progress if completed, consequences (positive, negative and somewhere in the middle at times), choices that are legit HARD to make...
You'll get to choose if a terrible man should die or live (after he butchers hundreds of women and doing God knows what to their bodies), pretty simple choice right?
You'll get to choose if a village should die to help a bunch of orphans and the sick wife of one of your ‚Äúfriends‚Ä? friend that caused said woman to become crazy after he beat her and led to her miscarriage.
You'll get to choose whether helping or not
, while also finding dead bodies in her house, that she forgot to mention.
That's why I compared it to Yakuza earlier. Both games have a pretty intense and well-written story (some moments are better than others, yea. None are flawless in terms of writing and pacing), but the sidequests
make the game shine, and these quests are just as important as the main quests, especially since some have SEVERE impacts on the story later on!
The best aspect about this game (
) is the morally grey choices. Some situation
have a good outcome, both outcomes are bad, some more, some less. The choice between lesser and greater evil is not omnipresent in the game but it's there in some crucial points.
.
The whole concept of ‚Ä?‚Ä?is at the center of the game, it's up to you to choose between them.
The Witcher 3 is an RPG, with your usual skill tree, armor and weapon upgrading system via runes, same old same old. You can use (
) mutagens to make your builds even stronger, all thanks to the usual skill points obtained when levelling up / completing certain actions and killing certain enemies that grant you special upgrades.
You'll have plenty of branches to this skill tree.
Combat ‚Ä?Combat moves, special attacks etc.
Spells ‚Ä?Sign upgrades, radical changes to the way some spells work (tired of your pocket flamethrower? Make it a
Potions ‚Ä?OD while also becoming scary and ugly to look at, which has its buff, not like real life
Witcher (I guess that's the name?) - Various specific buffs
You'll need to min-max your builds, fully maxing out your character in every single stat is doable, just not on 1-time playthrough. Some builds are clearly stronger than others, but you can mix and match lots of cool upgrades, giving you some freedom during combat and sometimes outside of it too.
Speaking of combat is ‚Ä?well, functional. It works, it's not the game's strongest aspect. It ‚Ä?it just works. It's simple: light and strong attack, block and parry (parry timing is a bit clunky tho), spice it up with 5 spells [ [i] Magic trap (not as cool as it sounds), Fire, Shield, Mind-control and Force Push[/i] ] and with the special skills from your skill tree. It's quite the challenge (
) at the highest difficulty, Death March, but even at lower difficulties the game's no joke... early on at least. You're far too weak early on, and once the story picks up the pace, you're overlevelled for the last main quests, making it a bit too easy later on. You'll go down easily, even with a great build, standing in one spot like a sitting duck taking blow after blow simply isn't a thing (
). You gotta keep on moving, and Geralt will dance around the battlefield like a crazy sword wielding ballerina, looking hella cool while slicing and dicing whatever comes in your way.
When it comes to loot you got your usual gear progression, the simple, usual ‚ÄúThe higher level you are, the cooler and stronger the gear gets‚Ä? Nothing much to add to that. It's easy to understand, it works.
The controls are bad, on PC at least. They work well during combat, they do work there yea... but horse riding, platforming and moving around in tight areas with a keyboard is a ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing pain. Your movements feel imprecise, clunky, which will then lead to falling... a lot. Fall damage is a true pain in the ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô? download a mod to remove it as soo

Seems to be seen as one of the best games ever made - I tried a year or so ago and go frustrated as you need to beat card players to get cards (in game mini game) and you can miss out if you dont get the right guy at the right time so I was told - anyways, game back then seemed solid but wasn't fussed about having to follow a guide in order to not miss out on stuff so left it.
Came back a couple years later due to Witcher series on TV and game it more of a proper go - I am still terrible at combat (gave up on Witcher 2 as couldn't make it past the tutorial on normal lol), but this is far more forgiving, less reliant on BS like oils, way more story and yeah it is looking like I might get to learn why people love this so much.
I would say I am about 12 hours in my second, real run on this, and yeah am barely scratching the surface i think - vastly better than previous witcher games (1 was collect all the girls you screwed cards, the game(tm), 2nd was no idea frankly as combat was too horrendous for me - this looks to be more of an epic, and if you suck at combat even more than me they even have an option to tone it down so much you can pretty much ignore it, which is nice really.  So yeah, I recommend, even for folks who are worried about twtich based, reflex combat - this has you covered and it is seriously very good - writing, environment, attention to detail, immersion- all top grade.  Just do yourself a favour and try it.

What else is there to say... this might be the best RPG of all time, as of 2020.  The amount of detail and content in the game is just massive.  There are no ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• fetch quests, every side quest has a bit of story that makes you actually want to do it, and not just for the rewards.  Biggest weakness for me was the combat feels a bit spin-to-win and low impact.

The praise for this game is not well-deserved due to the very basics: movement, looting, etc -- being unpleasant.
This game's biggest strength compared to titles heavily influenced by it, like Assassin's Creed: Odyssey, is that the side quests are actually interesting. They do a good job of generally avoiding pointless fetch quests. That's good, because you constantly get quests levels way above your current level. People criticized AC: Odyssey for XP grinding and content gating, yet I don't recall that being leveled against this game, which doe something fairly comparable. Puzzling.
This game has developed a reputation for being one of the best games ever made, and that is not a conclusion I think can be justified when core gameplay mechanics feel so unpleasant. Play it for the story and try to ignore the rest as best you can. Buy it when it's on sale.

I'd probably give this game an 8 or 9 out of 10. Had this game in my library for over two years before I gave it a try. Big mistake.  Very fun, great story that changes based on your choices, most quests are pretty engaging and enjoyable. I just finished the main quest line at 79 hours and haven't even started the DLCs yet. The combat is all 3rd person and feels similar to the Assassin's Creed games. There are no real stealth mechanics and I thought that would be a problem because that's usually how I go at most games but it was no problem at all. Definitely recommend especially if you can grab it on a $20 sale like I did.

Immersive,captivating and down right one of the best games visually and story I've played in a long time. over a hundred hours and I'm barely even scratching the surface on most quest and things to discover. Can honestly say its worth replaying over and over one completed.
Now for some of the issues:
Lighting inside houses and places that you're supposed to see well isn't that great and using the potion for seeing in the dark sometimes is still difficult.
The free market of trade is a bit one sided without an option to haggle for prices to go down or for what you're selling to go up. I'm a little peeved to sell something for 40 coin and then see to buy it back its worth 250..... inflation is legit a pain. but still manageable.
All in all i give it a 4.5 out of 5. The game play, scenery and story far surpass any issue I've come across and honestly while plying doesn't bother me to much. A game i can honestly say Id pay full price for and not flinch. Good hunting!!!

After giving it a shot for the third time, I must say this is a very deep and immersive RPG. I haven't played the first two Witcher games beyond 30 min, but you don't really need to have played them to understand what's going on. The beginning is quite slow, but it's necessary. It teaches you how to become a proper Witcher and sets the pace for the game going forward. The game is massive. I've played 26 hours now, doing all the side quests I can along the way, and I can already tell that I have at least over 100 hours more content to play, plus there's the DLC I'll be playing. There's a reason this is a masterpiece, and even having barely played much of it, I'm ready to call it just that.

If you like to waste most of your time navigating pages of clunky inventory menus, full of tiny icons, figuring out how to get the next missing thing, making tedious stuff over and over again, this game is for you. Dialogues, quests and characters are dumb, story is lackluster. Pseudo-slavic fantasy setting is not fun. Obvious bugs in inventory/trading system. Overall game pace is super slow and full of micro-management and tedious activities. Really bad system design in terms of upgrades and crafting. Inventory is full of stuff you never use. Game UI is just terrible. At this point of game where I currently am, I should have found at least one useful gear piece, but instead I have an inventory full of rubbish and unusable recipes. Environments and exploration are pretty good though.

Extremely immersive and fun! You don't need to complete Witcher 1 and 2 before playing this. It's like playing a game and watching a tv show in the same time. Storytelling is spot on! All the aspects...drama, humour, characters. Perfect. Combat system is simple yet challenging enough. It's not like one of those games where you have lots of combinations and if you take a break, return to the game weeks later and you forgot everything and are forced to restudy. Easy to learn, fun to master. Highly recommended! 10/10

If I'm honest this game is incredibly boring and tedious at the start. I did not really enjoy my experience (other than the graphics) for the first 10ish hours. After not giving up due to how much people praised it, I can now finally see what others have saw in this game.
It's not really about the gameplay or characters, since both of those elements are just average in my opinion. This game is actually about the immersion, world building, creatures, graphics and beautiful music that suck you into this game until you play for 6-hours straight. I don't think I've ever been this immersed in a game to the point I will just sit back and listen to the beautiful music and slowly take in the world and explore...this is the reason why people have 200+hours into this game (that and there's a lot of content). As of writing this review i'm 37 hours in and have so much to do and I definitely see myself doing almost everything this game has to offer (except the gwent card game quests...).
I highly recommend this game to those who want to go on an incredible journey and get sucked into an immersive cinematic world filled with interesting monsters, locations,lore and a listen to a great soundtrack. I can't exactly give a rating yet as I haven't finished the game or it's DLC. That said this game isn't for everyone, but I think most would enjoy it.

Evil/poor choices can be made that will lead to an awful ending, which makes achieving a good/bittersweet ending all the more satisfying. If you like epic soundtracks, this one is on par with best (Lord of the Rings, Star Wars, God of War PS4, Conan the Barbarian (1982). Of course you'll have to dig for those tracks, some of the best aren't even included on the official OST.

First: I haven't played any of the other games.
That said, it feels like they played through Skyrim, took note of every little annoying mechanic or issue, and made a better game that fixed every single one.
-Traveling on horse is tedious? Horses will follow a path if you just hold A.
-Diving underwater is generally pointless? There are plenty of loot caches underwater.
-Shout upgrades are just more of the same thing? Signs can change function with levels.
-‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• storytelling? Not an issue.
-Boring, two-step puzzles? Let's add some sick riddles.
I have only one complaint, and that's the fact sometimes the game gives you the illusion of choice when in fact both/all options lead to the same outcome. But just as often, the choice matters. So it's jarring sometimes.

This remains probably the best conceived and executed RPG ever made. It has 100+ hours of content on vanilla, a decently character build progression, and graphics that are more than good enough to stand the test of time.  It also has a good modding community, so if any of the small myriad game design choice bug you, or you want better graphics, you can make that happen too.
It's not perfect, your horse can be unreasonably stubburn, you can get stuck on scenery from time to time, and it's jarring how many people hate you, when you've spent your whole life being a hero, but it is what it is.

Oh man it's good, it's so ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing good, I don't even like fantasy games and I enjoyed every bit about this game except Foglets and annoying glitches like cutscenes not playing the game crashing when loading a prior save.
But other than that:
Combat: 8/10. Good but feels to shallow often turning into a dodge and hit fight, there are spells you can cast which are useful in fights but other than that it feels like a watered down Dark Souls, but it's still fun.
Story: 10/10. The games strongest aspect in my opinion. Starts of veeerrryyy slow for the first 3+hours but once you get the first big main quest out the way the story picks up and gets really immersive the characters don't feel like copies of each other (aside from their models which 80% of the time are if there not a main character) the only time it loses pace a bit is near the end when you do this big battle only for it be revealed that was just the start then the game returns back to normal while you go get the items needed (although in this last act they focus more on character development especially between Ciri and Geralt which is always a welcome choice) to finish what started. there are also about 15+ ending combinations you can get off the top of my head
World 9/10 the world of The Witcher 3 is not the largest but there is plenty to do from completing some witcher contracts which just means monster hunting to completing the massive amount of side quests which by the way are all unique and well designed a lot of side quests do have an impact on the story or characters so if a character you like gives you a side quest be sure to complete it (especially if its from Yen or Triss)
Top tier game. This is the proof a game can be art. Amazing story, amazing gameplay. thanks CDPR

If you're anything like me, and you don't enjoy playing "fantasy" style games, then this game probably doesn't seem too appealing. I'm really happy to say I was wrong.
No doubt one of the greatest games ever made. Perfectly designed, written, composed, and casted, this game is essential for any and every gamer to play. It's perfect for those who love a good story, those who love to be completionists, and... YES, even for those who hate fetch quests, as this game has none! Don't believe me? Try it yourself.
And the DLC's are 100% worth playing and are arguably better than the base game. Each area introduced is perfectly laid out, as you can really tell the developers spent a lot of time refining this game. I HIGHLY recommend this game to any type of gamer.
